text: A radiant shiny something dazzling in EXTREME CLOSEUP. BEGIN TITLES. CAMERA very slowly PULLS   BACK. The sparkling surface turns out to be a lot of   carats. WE SEE the stone, then the ring, then suddenly,   in b.g., something HUGE SWEEPS by. REVEAL a mechanical    claw above the ring, hanging from a crane. The ring    sits in a sea of tiny dolls, joke eyeballs, and other   carnival junk. The claw descends on the ring again and again, sometimes catching it for a moment then tragically dropping it -- accompanied by OOHS and AAHS (O.S.) of hope and disap- pointment. INTERCUT with the HANDS of a young black man working the controls. The EYES of a young black woman watching him work. Another guy's HANDS digging in his pocket for change. QUARTERS going into the slot.
This'll never work, Tommy.
Be positive, Armando. Course it will. The claw inadvertently snags a rabbit's foot.
Look.   See what a lucky fuck I am?
He don't mean the ring, hon, he means the whole plan.

So do I. The claw catches the   ring and closes on it. QUICK CUTS of their FACES as the   crane rises. A very pretty lady. A beefy Latino with a   two-day beard. Their apprehension Tommy's confidence.    Then his exceptional smile. He get the ring.
Okay -- one down, one to go. (returning to the claw)
You got quarters, Loretta? END TITLES. THE DISTINGUISHED GENTLEMAN - Rev. 4/3/92              2.
Palm trees. The smell of money. Valets in Foreign Legion khakis greeting arriving luxury cars.

A big crowd of GUESTS at a cocktail reception. A lot of lime jackets, cherry trousers, and blue hair. People wear name tags. ON Tommy, in pastel bow tie and full waiter drag, con- firming orders for a group of guests. He speaks in a

That's a diet ginger ale, an extra- spicy virgin mary no salt, a club soda -- good choice -- a lime rickey, and a bourbon and a planter's punch. Five people, five drinks... it's Kismet! Tommy turns away, looking toward the entrance to the room.
glittering on Loretta's finger. LORETTA, stunning in designer clothing and accessories, enters. Her looks attract looks.
Tommy, maintaining his vantage point, repeats another order, this time in a heavy CARRIBEAN ACCENT:

That's a vodka tonic, a Pellegrino, lime and no ice, a gin Gibson straight up with ex-tra onions -- I am also fond of de onions -- and a Chardonnary spritzer...also with extra onions -- no, no, do not worry, that is just a little joke. There will be no onions whatsoever in your spritzer! He LAUGHS HUGELY, rather amused with himself.   The guest aren't.
You don't need to write it down?
THE DISTINGUISHED GENTLEMAN - Rev. 4/3/92            3.
Mr. Memory?   Do not make me laugh! He LAUGHS HUGELY, turns, takes two steps away and makes absolutely no effort to get their drinks. He looks toward the door.

Loretta approaches the function room, where pert  DEBBIE, wearing a JOHNSON FOR CONGRESS button, staffs a  felt- covered table. On  a nearby easel, a photo of a  silver- haired Man with a legend in blue and gold: JEFF   JOHNSON THE NAME YOU KNOW.
sense_profile: the function room , where pert DEBBIE , wearing a JOHNSON FOR CONGRESS button , staffs a felt- covered table

text: (Eurotrash accent)
I'm not too late, am I, dear? (extending a hand)
Hello, darling, Alma Preston, how are you today?
Thanks for coming, Ms. Preston, I'm Debbie Bartle. (consulting a list)
Do we have your check yet? Loretta pulls a Mont Blanc pen and a checkbook from her bag.
sense_profile: a Mont Blanc pen and a checkbook from her bag

text: No, honey, I don't think you do, we just got in last night from our place in Barbados -- how much is it?
Five hundred a person.   Barbados?
(writing)
Yes, we're just down the beach from Mick Jagger and Jerry. (looking up)
You wouldn't turn down a couple of thousand, would you? A pleased smile from Debbie. Loretta opens the check- book, flashing the immense RING in front of Debbie.
Um, that's a lovely ring.
THE DISTINGUISHED GENTLEMAN - Rev. 4/3/92              4.
Oh, thank you. I thought it might be a little gaudy...who should I make this out to?
Johnson for Congress. It's not gaudy, it's just...nice and big.
That's my Carlos...I can't even look in a store window. We're walking down this street in Rio, we pass a jewelry store...I didn't even turn my head and he's in the shop... (holds up ring)
...$250,000. I said it's crazy... but you know Carlos.
I wish I did. ON Tommy watching Loretta. A Guest standing just behind Tommy -- wearing MRS. ZEKE BRIDGES name tag -- watches JEFF JOHNSON gladhand the room robustly.
I hear they had him open for six hours. ZEKE, a very fat cigar-smoker, marvels at Johnson's appearance.
(chuckling)
The sum' bitch looks terrific. Tommy, eavesdropping, joins Zeke's chuckle, which unfor- tunately turns into a wheeze and then a cough. Zeke turns to Tommy.
How about taking our orders, son?
Absolutely my friend!    How can I pleasure you?
Bourbon straight up and a Perrier rocks for the lady.
THE DISTINGUISHED GENTLEMAN - Rev. 4/3/92             5.
Ah! Fire and ice! Wonderful! But may I suggest you make that a double sir? After all, so many guests, so few of me -- who knows when I may be back?
Sure, why not. AT THE ENTRANCE LORETTA pauses before going into the room
You know where the powder room is, hon? I should freshen my face before I go in.
It's just over there. ON JEFF JOHNSON with his well-groomed wife, VERA, and a barrel-chested Man in full resort wear, wearing an OLAF ANDERSEN name tag.
So how the heck are you, Olaf?
I should be asking how you are, congressman. Johnson pats his chest and smiles at Vera.
This old ticker never felt better.
It's good to see you back on your feet, Jeff. We need you in Washington. Inconspicuously, a pretty young redhead whispers to Vera. This is JENNIFER, Johnson's Administrative Assistant (his AA).
How's that granddaughter of yours, Olaf? Ready for the Olympics?

She'll be thrilled you asked after her. 8   IN THE HALLWAY Loretta emerges from the Ladies' Room. catches a spike heel... recovers her balance... then frantically searches her hands and clothes, SCREAMS, and gets down on hands and knees.
THE DISTINGUISHED GENTLEMAN - Rev. 4/3/92             6.
My God!    My God! Oh my God! Debbie rushes over to her.
What's the matter?
(hyperventilating)
My --   my ring. My diamond. I took it off   in the ladies' room to wash my hands.    I was just putting it on -- I must   have dropped it.
(getting down)
Let me help you, we'll find it.
Call Security! 9   IN THE FUNCTION ROOM Tommy maintains his watch on Loretta. Zeke Bridges taps Tommy on the shoulder.
Hey, what about our drinks? Tommy instantly assumes an ANGRY YOUNG STREET BLACK
Yeah?    What you want?
What?    You already took our order.
That wasn't me! You must be thinking of Jamal. I'm Karim. What you want?
Bourbon straight up and a Perrier rocks.
(snorts derisively)
Hunh. He walks two steps...and once again makes no attempt to get the drinks. Zeke returns to Jeff Johnson.
sense_profile: no attempt to get the drinks

text: THE DISTINGUISHED GENTLEMAN - Rev. 4/3/92             7.

Don't get me wrong, Jeff. Pyramid Insurance doesn't want special breaks. I just think we ought to be able to set our own rates without Uncle Sam sticking his nose in our business. Johnson signals Jennifer to come over.
Do you know my AA? Zeke Bridges, this is Jennifer, my Administrative Assistant. Zeke's been a tremendous help to us. I'd like you to listen to his view on health insurance.
I'd be very happy to.

At Pyramid Insurance, we call our approach the Patient's Bill of Rights. 10   IN THE HALLWAY Loretta and Debbie are on hands and knees, still looking. A pair of shoes comes INTO FRAME. They LOOK up at a bullet-headed man.
Ms. Preston?   Bruno Handler, hotel security.
My ring!   My ring! Oh my god...!
Now just calm down, Ma'am... can you describe the ring?
It's a diamond ring! A big diamond ring! Oh my Christ! She's frantic.   Debbie takes Bruno aside.
I saw it. It's huge... it must be like eight carats. She says it was a quarter of a million dollars! Bruno turns back to Loretta, trying to calm her.
THE DISTINGUISHED GENTLEMAN - Rev. 4/3/92             8.
Ma'am... calm down.   Now, is the ring insured?

Of course it's insured! But you know how it works -- if I report it, they'll cancel me. And I don't want another ring! I need this ring! The ring Carlos gave me. Bruno turns, speaks into the walkie-talkie he's carrying.

Where the fuck is housekeeping? I called for those dickheads ninety seconds ago. 11   IN THE FUNCTION ROOM the Guests have gathered to hea Johnson speak. As Andersen introduces him, Tommy con- tinues eyeing Loretta.

Now I won't run through Jeff's record -- he's been in Congress twenty years, and I've only got two minutes. I'll just say this: When those of us in pharmaceuticals, or agribusiness, or insurance, or (indicating himself)
utilities, or you name it -- when we've needed him, Jeff's been there for us. And we've been there for Jeff, too -- we raised a hundred thousand dollars today! (APPLAUSE)
Without further ado, our man in Washington, Jefferson Davis Johnson. 12   IN THE HALLWAY Debbie hears the APPLAUSE (O.S.).   S gets up.
I should be in there. Good luck, Ms. Preston. I hope you find it. She leaves.   Loretta, mascara smeared, gets up, as does Bruno.
I can't go in there like this. God! Please... listen... I'll pay a ten thousand dollar reward for anybody who finds my ring. Just don't tell Carlos! (suddenly grim)
He'll kill me. THE DISTINGUISHED GENTLEMAN - Rev. 4/3/92            9. 13   IN THE FUNCTION ROOM, as Johnson takes questions, To slips out.
What do you make of all this campaign reform business, Jeff?

Well, y'know Ernie... these days, everyone's down on the political action committees and so-called special interests. But, heck, I think you and Fran have a right to participate in our democracy in exactly the way you're doing today. I'm in Congress to represent you. I don't want any so-called reform to take that power away from you. 14   APPLAUSE (O.S.). IN THE HALLWAY Bruno issues orders two Maintenance Men.

I want every heating grate opened and inspected. I want every air conditioning duct vacuumed. Do you understand what I'm saying? AS he speaks, Bruno SEES Tommy pass through the hallway ... spot something on the floor... pick it up... furtive- ly put it in his pocket... and walk rapidly toward the door to the kitchens.
(running after him)
Hey, you! Waiter! Hold it right there! Bruno puts an arm on Tommy. Tommy instantly assumes a frantic, wimpy, craven persona, along wth his CARRIBBEAN ACCENT.
No! Please! Do not report me! I will be deported!
Calm down.   What've you got in your pocket?
I told the CIA everything! I agreed to poison the pineapples! My green card is in the mail!
THE DISTINGUISHED GENTLEMAN - Rev. 4/3/92             10.
Stow it! I'm not Immigration, I'm hotel security. Now, what did you just put in your pocket?
Nothing.
I'm warning you, flathead, get cute with me and I will tear you a second asshole. Now a valuable diamond ring is mising...
Valuable? We can almost see the light bulb click on above Bruno's head.
Very valuable. All right, I'll give you a hunnert bucks for it.
A hundred and five? Bruno snorts agreement, goes for his wallet... Tommy goes gor the ring... then suddenly leaps back in a cringe!
No! It's a trick! You will call me a thief and send me back and the Security Police will make me stand on my head in the guano pit! I have seen such things on
Bruno snaps and GRABS TOMMY BY THE COLLAR.
Jesus, I'm not trying to trick you...
No, no... it is a trap! I must turn this over to police. He starts to leave.   Bruno grabs him.
THE DISTINGUISHED GENTLEMAN - Rev. 4/3/92              11
Listen, dipshit... a valuable ring is missing and there's thousands of dollars in reward money waiting. So you'd better fork over...
How big is this... reward? Another lightbulb.
Um, five hundred dollars.
You said 'thousands.'
Yeah.     Right.    A thousand dollars.
No, no, no...you said thousands. With an 'S'. This is plural. This means "two or more thousands."
(deep sigh)
Okay, you win. Two thousand.
Or more.     Two or more. Bruno's had enough -- his grip tightens around Tommy's neck.
Just making a point. 15   IN HOTEL LOBBY AT THE CASHIER'S DESK Bruno slides a check to the Cashier, who counts a stack of bills. Bruno picks up a house phone, dials.
ARMANDO, still unshaven, answers the RINGING phone.
Hello? INTERCUT with Bruno in the lobby.
Hello, may I speak with Ms. Preston?
THE DISTINGUISHED GENTLEMAN - Rev. 4/3/92              12
She's in the bathroom. This is Carlos. Can I take a message?
(smiling to himself)

No, thanks, I'll call back. ARMANDO hangs up the phone and exits the hotel room. BRUNO crosses to the far side of the lobby, where Tommy waits inconspicuously. He gives him the money. Tommy gives him ring.
Now get back to work! As Tommy heads back to the function room, Bruno picks up a house phone, dials, listens. He dials again, listens. No answer. He dials the operator.

This is Bruno in Security. Put me through to 502 -- there must be something wrong with the line, I can't get an answer... What do you mean, there's no one in 502? I just spoke to them!... No one's registered in 502? Are you sure?... Well, check again!... Shit! He hangs up, looks at the ring, and realizes he's been taken. His face twisting with rage, he hurries after Tommy. 17   ON TOMMY MOVING swiftly through the function room to an exit. Zeke Bridges grabs him.
Hey!   Where the hell are our drinks. Surprised, Tommy opts for an EAST INDIAN ACCENT.
I remember... you were the sloe gin fizz and the mango daquiri? With perhaps a small umbrella for the lady?
Bourbon neat and a Perrier, dammit!
And would you still be wanting the umbrella then?
THE DISTINGUISHED GENTLEMAN - Rev. 4/3/92             13.
As Zeke's face flushes in anger, Tommy SEES Bruno come into the room, blood in his eye. Tommy turns sharply and heads out the terrace doors to the --
Tommy conceals himself behind a pillar, across the court- yard, away from the Guests. But from another direction, Johnson and Andersen approach, arm in arm, and sit on a bench by the pillar.
Olaf, there's something I wanted to sound you out on. As a special friend.
Shoot. Tommy moves away from the pillar, sees Bruno roaming the terrace, and retreats.
I'm thinking of retiring from Congress. Andersen's eyes widen in astonishment.
You're what?
I'm thinking maybe I won't run. Maybe I should listen more (indicating his heart)
to this. Really appreciate these years. Sail around the world. Climb mountains. Enjoy the finer things of life.
Jeff. Listen to me. You can't retire. Florida needs you. I need you. I need you on rates. I need you on regulations. I need you on those environmental nutcases --
Olaf, if I retire this year, I get to keep all the money left over in my campaign treasury. Comes to a very tidy nest-egg.
How tidy?
THE DISTINGUISHED GENTLEMAN - Rev. 4/3/92             14.
One-point-three million. (chuckles)
It's called the grandfather loophole. Bruno has gone.   But Tommy stays.   His eyes light up at the money.

Come on, Jeff. Look at what you'd be giving up. Going to the best resorts in the world and calling it "official business." Golfing and skiing and fishing, and never picking up a tab. And, Jeff -- there's no aphrodisiac like power. You can have some of the most intelligent, attractive women in the country. You've got it made!
Oh, I suppose that one-point-three may seem like spare change to the head of Gulf Coast Power, but to a country boy like me --

Okay, Jeff. I get it. Look. There's a little software company that's about to go through the roof. Johnson smiles at the direction the conversation is taking. ON Tommy also smiling, in admiration at the transaction going down.

A few thousand worth of stock options would stand to make you quite a pile. As long as your blind trust buys them, you're clean -- the SEC can't shake a stick at you. Half a million, easy -- and that's just a start.
Well, if you put it like that... I now see I have a duty to continue my career in public service. Johnson stands, puts his arm on Andersen. Tommy emerges, shakes his head, and laughs.
I'm in the wrong business. THE DISTINGUISHED GENTLEMAN - Rev. 4/3/92

A ramshackle bait shack, paint peeling, on the inland waterway. At the rear of the shack, Armando shoots hoops into a tattered net. Loretta, back in jeans, looks at her watch. A bondo-patched Econoline van pulls up. Tommy jumps out, big smile. He gives Loretta an energetic round of APPLAUSE.
sense_profile: At the rear of the shack

text: The best li'l roper in America! But she doesn't want the charm.
You took your time.
Cops bust you, Tommy?
Busted?   Moi?    Fuck no. He pulls out the wad of bills.       Their faces brighten considerably.
That look like busted?
Washington, D.C.   The illuminated dome of the Capitol.

CAMERA ROAMS the well-hung walls. From the photos and memorabilia, we realize that we are in the office of Rep. Jeff Johnson. In the reflections on the frames, we GLIMPSE some MOVEMENT on the desk explaining the considerable BREATHING and MOANING (O.S.).
sense_profile: that we are in the office of Rep. Jeff Johnson

text: Oh my God.     Oh my God. Oh my... But then a strange GURGLING sound (O.S.) escapes from Johnson.
... God. A silent beat.   Then a horrified CRY.      Jennifer rise INTO FRAME.
Oh my god! THE DISTINGUISHED GENTLEMAN - Rev. 4/3/92            14B.

The congregation is SINGING. We SEE the widow Johnson. At her side, in the aisle seat, a powerful man with bushy eyebrows, about 60, in a three-piece suit and watch chain: congressman DICK DODGE. The HYMN ends. Dodge steps up to the pulpit.

It was my honor to serve in Congress with Jeff Johnson for a generation. No one could have been a better legislator. No one could have been a finer husband and father. And now -- He presses the tips of his fingers together and looks skyward, as if communing with his memory of the deceased.
And now God has called his servant home. ANGLE ON Jennifer, in black.
We will miss him. But we are grateful that his passing was so peaceful -- and so like him -- working late into the night at his desk, the consummate public servant.
Vera sneaks a look at Jennifer, who is poker-faced.
On the veranda of the gracious  home, mourners pay respects to the family. Dodge   puts a gentle hand on the widow's shoulder and draws  her aside. He throws a look at Jennifer, who joins  them.
Vera, I know you're still in shock from Jeff's... passing. But we have to talk about his seat. Vera stares at Jennifer.   She knows the score.
Mrs. Johnson, if you'd like to discuss this in private --
You can stay -- what's the difference?

Vera, I'd like you to announce that you're going to run for Congress. Let a few days pass to show proper respect. But next week, I want to stand next to you at a press conference where you declare for Jeff's seat in the House.
No, Dick -- no.
There's nothing to be afraid of, Vera. With your name, you can't lose. People around these parts are so used to voting for Jeff Johnson -- why, Mrs. Jeff Johnson would win in a walk.
Dick, I was a Washington wife for twenty years. Twenty years of Potomac bullshit is plenty for one lifetime.
Vera, we're talking about becoming a Member of Congress. We're talking about a sure thing.
THE DISTINGUISHED GENTLEMAN - Rev. 4/3/92              16
Don't worry about running the office -- I'll be there night and day.
I'm sure you would, dear. But I couldn't give you the same job satisfaction Jeff gave you. Jennifer, embarrassed, didn't know Vera knew.    Nor did Dodge.
A retirement community in the Florida sunshine.

open. A supermarket shopping cart full of groceries, tied with a big bow, rolls out, pushed by Tommy. Loretta accompanies him. Tommy BUZZES at a door. It's answered by Tommy's GRANDMA, a limber lady in leggings and a bright top. She sees the groceries, kisses him.
sense_profile: A supermarket shopping cart full of groceries , tied with a big bow

text: This is very sweet of you, darling. But you shouldn't have done it. Where did you get the money?
You don't want to know.
Tommy and Loretta are watching the track results on the local tv news. Tommy, playing solitaire, shuffles bril- liantly. Grandma comes in from the kitchen, shaking her head.
How did I end up with a thief for a grandson?
Grandma -- I told you.    I'm not a thief. I'm a con man.     An artist.
But also a crook.
THE DISTINGUISHED GENTLEMAN - Rev. 4/3/92             17.
But I only con crooks, Grandma. You can't con an honest man. Only somebody who wants something for nothing. (pause)
But the good Lord must have been fond of pigeons, because he made so many of them.
Sometimes I just wish you were more like your Daddy...
You mean, dead?
No, smartmouth... I mean someone who made something of himself.
(pointing at TV)
LOOK...it's the ad! VIDEO...a cheap TV spot -- a busty blonde in a skimpy outfit tossing her hair and pouting.
(fake Swedish accent)
I am Inga. I'm here from Sweden and I'm s-o-o lonely. I need a man...and so do my girlfriends. VIDEO...Scantily-clad babes to match the names.    Lorett speaks along with the V.O.
...Maria, my hotblooded Spanish friend...Babette, the Parisian pussycat...and many others. So call the "Girls of Many Nations," at 1-900-555-NATO. SUPER:   CALL 1-900-555-NATO.
(Swedish accent)
So what do you think of my accent, Grandma?
Compared to what? Loretta, why don't you go baste the turkey?
THE DISTINGUISHED GENTLEMAN - Rev. 4/3/92               1
Loretta gets up and goes for the kitchen. We hear a high-pitched ELECTRONIC WARBLE. Tommy reaches into Loretta's purse and pulls out a cellular phone.
sense_profile: a high - pitched ELECTRONIC WARBLE. Tommy reaches into Loretta 's purse and pulls out a cellular phone

text: (calls to Loretta)
See?      I told you TV advertising works. He opens the phone and speaks in a toneless, recording- like voice.
Hello...you have reached Girls of Many Nations. For Hot Blooded Italian Wildcats, press "one" now. (nothing)
For Perky American Cheerleaders, press "two" now. (nothing)
For a Sultry Swedish Love Goddess, press "three" now... ("BEEP")
He covers the mouthpiece and calls to Loretta.
Bingo! Loretta...guy wants to speak to Inga.
Tell him to call back.      I'm basting. TOMMY grins mischievously and speaks into the phone in the husky voice of a SWEDISH WOMAN.
Ja, this is Inga. Hello Paul... how are you tonight? You are feeling naughty? That's all right ...you have your what in a bowl of oatmeal? Yes, that is very naughty, and maybe a little sick.
Disgusting.
THE DISTINGUISHED GENTLEMAN - Rev. 4/3/92             19.
Oh NO! It's my husband Lars. He's home early, I must go before ...you want to talk to Lars too? So you like to talk dirty out of both sides of your mouth. (normal voice)
Man, you are one twisted bastard! Laughing, he hangs up.
Tommy, please!
Sorry, grandma, just getting a third minute out of him. He clicks off the phone and slams it back into Loretta's purse. Loretta, meanwhile, has reappeared.
You hung up on Paul? He's one of my best customers.
I can't believe any relative of mine does that for a living.
C'mon Gramma...it's only my voice. They never actually meet me.
So my granddaughter talks dirty for a living and my grandson's a thief.
What's up, Grandma? Are you embarrassed to show my picture around the pool?
Of course I'm not. Look. She goes to her sewing basket and pulls something from it. She unfolds it: a long piece of needlepoint she's been working on.
It spells out Tommy's full name:   Thomas Jefferson Johnson.
THE DISTINGUISHED GENTLEMAN - Rev. 4/3/92             20.
Look what these arthritic hands been doing.
Make me proud of you, Tommy. Make me proud of the name you carry. In the silence between them that follows, we HEAR the tv.

I'm Ned Grable, vice president and general manager of WFLA. We think Mrs. Jeff Johnson did the right thing in not running for the congressional seat left vacant by her husband's death. The editorial catches Grandma's attention.
Jeff Johnson's name may still be magic. But it'll take more than the magic of name recognition to solve our region's problems. I'm Ned Grable.
Name recognition. Lordy, what a notion. People have to be some boobs just to vote for someone because their name is Johnson. Tommy's eyes widen.
I remember once back in Georgia, they even elected a dead man. His name was still on the ballot -- people were just used to voting for him.
What did you say, Grandma?
HOMER, the proprietor of Homer's Pit Stop, wearing fuel- smeared overalls, is dieseling a Customer's boat down by the water.
Homer!    Get your ass over here!
THE DISTINGUISHED GENTLEMAN - Rev. 4/3/92               2
Up by the racks of junk food and beer, and pails of fish slop, Tommy and Armando await Homer. In b.g., an older black gentleman plays checkers, solo. This is VAN DYKE.
What's this about, jefe?
(calling)
Loretta! Get off the damn phone!
This better be good.
(sarcastic mimic)
"This better be good." Loretta! ON LORETTA on the pay phone, moaning in Swedish ecstasy.
Oh, ya, ya, God, you're so big! (waving at Tommy)
Uh-oh, I have to go now, my husband Sven is home early... Tommy grabs the phone.   He pushes aside a protesting Loretta...
Goddammit, Inga, is it that pervert again! Damn! He smacks the receiver with his hand.
(into receiver)

Listen, you little shit -- I just spent eight years in the joint, nobody talks to my woman like that! I got your adress, I got a machete, I got two Rotweilers... I'm gonna come to your house and tear your ass up! (hangs up, laughing)
Okay, Tommy, what's so damn important?
Yeah, I got work to do.
THE DISTINGUISHED GENTLEMAN - Rev. 4/3/92            21.
They all look at him expectantly. He takes a dramatic pause, then launches into a "Come to Jesus" speech.
sense_profile: into a " Come to Jesus " speech

text: My friends, I want to tell you about a town where the streets are paved with gold. This is a town where the marks give you money before you ask. A town where they take you to dinner after you fuck 'em. A town where when they need money, they just print more. This is a town where a guy bounced nine hundred checks and he didn't even have to skip town!!!
Ain't no town like that.
You mean Vegas?
No. (beat)
Washington, D.C.   I'm going to run for Congress. His big smile meets their blank surprise.   Their faces fall.
What is this, a joke?
I don't get it.
What's the con, Tommy?
Van Dyke.   You remember Willie Sutton?
Of blessed memory.
You remember what he said? They asked him, Why do you rob banks? And he said, That's where the money is. I tell you, people -- Washington. That's where the money is.
THE DISTINGUISHED GENTLEMAN - Rev. 4/3/92            22.
Tommy produces a sheaf of Xeroxes and pamphlets.
sense_profile: a sheaf of Xeroxes and pamphlets

text: I found this shit in the library. You know how much a congressman makes? A hundred and thirty a year -- and that's just base pay for getting your ass elected. Then there are these things called PACs, and these lobbyists, whose whole point in life is to buy you off. It's the con of a lifetime -- and the damn thing is, it's legal! This is hot, people, we can do this!
Who "we," white man?
You never heard of staff, Armando? I get in, I get a staff allowance of five hundred and thirty-seven grand a year -- Loretta wolf-WHISTLES.
-- which I will generously share with you.
And how exactly were you going to get your butt to Congress?
Yeah -- why would anyone vote for you?

Not for me, Homer. For Jeff Johnson. Name recognition -- that's what it's all about. You think folks know their congressman died? I get on the ballot as Jeff Johnson, I guarantee they'll vote for me. Now all's I have to do is get on the ballot.
Which is how?
THE DISTINGUISHED GENTLEMAN - Rev. 4/3/92           23.
Which is where you folks come in. (picking up a ream of forms)
All's we have to do is collect five thousand six hundred twenty five signatures.
You shittin' us?
In your dreams, Tommy.
You people got a better idea?
I do.
Senior citizens fold brochures, stuff envelopes, make phone calls. Van Dyke and Tommy enter.
Okay... gimme the four-one-one on these Silver Foxes Again. It's a bunch of old folks who like to vote?
Don't laugh, they get an enormous turnout. But the big thing is, they have their own line on the ballot. They already got the signatures.
Ah.
The lady we're meeting, Hattie Rifkin, they call her the condo queen.
So all I have to do is snow one old lady. Don't sound like major surgery. THE DISTINGUISHED GENTLEMAN - Rev. 4/3/92            24.
Tommy and Van Dyke are seated opposite HATTIE RIFKIN, a high-energy woman, 70s, with a frizz of white curls.
So, what brings you here?   You want to talk politics... talk!
We were wondering who you were going to run for Congress this year.
Oh, the usual sacrifical lamb. Probably Sylvia Roland. She just lost her husband, she needs to meet new people. Why?
Mrs. Rifkin... I want to run.
Well, I want to run too -- but with this plastic hip, it's not gonna happen. Tommy breaks up.   In spite of himself, he's charmed by t salty old babe.
What I mean is... I'd like to run for Congress on the Silver Fox ticket. I care about you and your issues.
Yeah, that's what my son says. But does he call? Anyway, what makes you think a group of alter cockers are gonna support a man who hasn't clipped his first nose hair yet?
Because I can win.
No, no... a Democrat can win. A Republican can win. A Silver Fox can only make a symbolic point.
Mrs. RIfkin, if you give me a ballot line, and if I can get support from...
THE DISTINGUISHED GENTLEMAN - Rev. 4/3/92            25.
If... if. Ven die bubbah halla tsehen qulishkes, het gehaya zadeh.
Sure, but... besser die viller ein der kenner. Hattie cracks up.   Tommy leans over and translates for Van Dyke:
She said, 'If my grandmother had balls, she'd be my grandfather.'
(recovering)
Where the Hell did you learn to speak Yiddish?
The same place I learned to hustle shtarkers at gin rummy. From Morris Elfbein... the Gin King of Miami Beach.
No kidding... you knew the Rudolf Valentino of Dade County?
He taught me a great deal. He taught me you don't always need the best cards to win.
Maybe not in gin, but in politics, young man, you need money to win, you need a name to win, you...
Oh, I have a name.
What, you're an athlete, a movie star? I don't get out as much as I used to. You're not on MTV, are you?
No ma'am. My name is Johnson.      Jeff Johnson. The Name You Know.
THE DISTINGUISHED GENTLEMAN - Rev. 4/3/92
She ponders for a minute.    And then she gets it.   A wicked smile.
Jeff Johnson. Well,     that's a name even our Alzheimer's    Group will remember. (beat; shakes    her head)
Still, for a full-up    campaign, we'd need materials, we'd    need ads...
You leave that to me, Mrs. R.
The widow Johnson is pouring tea for Tommy, now in super- nerd drag -- wire-rim glasses and tweed sport jacket.
I'm not sure I understand, Professor Franklin -- you wrote your doctoral thesis on my husband?
He was a great man, Mrs. Johnson. He did so much for my people.
He... did?
Oh, yes. I'll never forget when he said 'Welfare is a drug -- and you gotta kick it cold turkey.' It was... inspirational.
Really... well, I'm sure...
And I was actually in the audience when he said, 'If you people would just get off your dead asses and look for work, this country might be fit to live in again.' Powerful stuff.
It's very kind of you to say so. And you're very kind to come all the way from... where was it?
THE DISTINGUISHED GENTLEMAN - Rev. 4/3/92            27.

Wilson-Pickett State Teachers College. But I didn't just come to pay respects, ma'am. I came because your husband deserves an archive. A place where scholars can study his legacy. A storehouse for the record of his remarkable career.
I see.   So you want... his papers?

Oh, not just his papers, Mrs. Johnson. Everything. Buttons, posters, bumper stickers. All the paraphernalia of his campaigns -- proof of his political genius. Now I realize that you may have a sentimental attachment to a few items...
Take 'em.
I beg your pardon.
Take 'em all. Would you like the wedding photos, too?
Well, I don't think that's necess...
Good -- that way you won't have to go rooting around in the garbage. Is there anything else?
Well, um... no.
More tea?   Or something stronger? I know it's  only ten-thirty, but, hell, sun's  over the yardarm somewhere,  right?
Actually, ma'am, I should be getting back.
THE DISTINGUISHED GENTLEMAN - Rev. 4/3/92            28.
You're in pretty good shape for a professor. D'you work out? Tommy rises and packs his briefcase hastily.
Look, I, um, have a class to teach. You know how blind students are... they're so dependent. (edges toward door)
Don't worry ma'am... your materials will be in good hands.

cuts the RE- off a RE-ELECT JEFF JOHNSON bumper sticker in familiar blue and gold. Van Dyke, Armando, and Homer have a production line going doctoring the old Johnson campaign materials, slicing off and painting out the RE-'s and the years.
Are you sure you don't want to come to Washington with us, Homer?
You bums got time on your hands. (indicating bait shack)
I got a business to run. ON LORETTA working the RINGING pay phone.
Hello? Who? The League of Women Voters? Sorry, Mr. Johnson won't be attending the debate. No -- no, Betty, I'm sorry, I can't tie up this line. (hangs up; it RINGS)
Hello? The Sarasota Star-Ledger? I'm sorry, we're out of photographs. No, you can't, Mr. Johnson has just had surgery for a deviated septum. (hangs up; it RINGS)
Hello? (brightening)
Ya, this is Inga. PAN TO TOMMY training a home video camera on a poster tha reads JEFF JOHNSON FOR CONGRESS.
sense_profile: PAN TO TOMMY training a home video camera on a poster tha

text: THE DISTINGUISHED GENTLEMAN - Rev. 4/3/92             29.
(very white)

We're not going to show you Jeff Johnson waving a flag. We're not going to show you Jeff Johnson kissing babies. We're not going to show you Jeff Johnson doing anything, because you already know what Jeff Johnson can do.
The poster fills the screen.
Tomorrow, vote for Jeff Johnson. The name you know. A very puzzled Vera Johnson watches the ad on tv.

The congressional district sleeps. But   in the darkness, a kind of D-Day onslaught is under way.   QUICK SUPER- IMPOSED CUTS of Tommy's secret army of  Silver Foxes, opening crates, fanning through parking  lots, swarming over lawns, driving in stakes, tacking  up posters everywhere. INCLUDE Tommy climbing a telephone pole... Armando shinny up a light pole across the street... Loretta and Van Dyke pulling on a rope... which hoists a huge bundle to Tommy. who opens and unfolds it... and gets an end through the air to Armando. They unfurl the biggest banner imaginable
sense_profile: unfolds it ... and gets an end through the air to Armando

text: CAMERA TILTS DOWN. Every square    inch of town seems to have been plastered with JOHNSON   FOR CONGRESS material. It's on billboards, bumpers, bus   shelters, balloons, banners, utility poles... all in   the late congressman's signature design.

The Econoline, now a JOHNSON ad on wheels, ghetto-blaster mounted front and back on the roof, rolls by a Jewish del ...a soul food joint... a whitebread country club... a Chinese restaurant... At each, Tommy's amplified VOICE sa
THE DISTINGUISHED GENTLEMAN - Rev. 4/3/92             30.
Jeff Johnson.    The name you know. In a different appropriate accent.

In front of a polling place, Van Dyke pulls up in a hears with an ELECT JOHNSON banner. So, driving muscle cars, do Armando, Homer, and Loretta -- Tommy's get-out-the-vote f Exhilarated senior citizens pile out, led by Hattie.
sense_profile: a hears with an ELECT JOHNSON banner

text: An ordinary Couple, 40s, sign the registration book, then enter adjacent voting carrels. After a moment, the HUSBAND leans out.
Who are we voting for Congress?
Don't we always vote for Johnson?
That's it -- Johnson. HIS HAND punches the hole in the ballot next to Johnson.
A NETWORK ANCHOR at an election-night news set.
If you're just joining us, our exit polls project that in Florida, an unknown, independent candidate whose sole asset appears to be his name may just possibly win a slim victory.
thru 42

Blinding lights. Media circus.     TV power cords, a huge tangle snaking back toward mobile   generators. Cameramen narrowly miss knocking each other   into the water. A STEEL DRUM BAND plays "Happy Days   Are Here Again."
sense_profile: knocking each other into the water

text: THE DISTINGUISHED GENTLEMAN - Rev. 4/3/92             31.
The small crowd -- Tommy's cronies, their pals, and a jubilant contingent of Panthers led by Hattie -- lets out a great WHOOP.

Is that him? Tricia, I believe Congressman-elect Johnson is coming this way. For the first time, we see Tommy wearing a beautifully-cu suit. He's instantly engulfed by lights, cameras, and Supporters. An amazed CAMERAMAN, watching Tommy, whispers to a Produc
Jesus -- he's not... white. I actually voted for the guy. I thought he was Jeff Johnson. Tommy jumps onto a bench.    APPLAUSE from his Supporters

Thank you, thank you, all of you, for your help. Give yourself a round of applause. They do. As APPLAUSE continues (O.S.), CAMERA PANS from Reporter to Reporter to Reporter, their mikes bearing the call-letters of different channels. ON GRANDMA being interviewed. She wears a JOHNSON FOR CONGRESS button and speaks with manifest pride.

I've never been so proud in all my life. He was always such a good boy...well, I think he meant well. Sometimes -- well he was a clean child. That's important, I think... PAN TO FLORIDA REPORTER #2 doing a stand-up.
Then in Massachusetts, there was a guy named Kennedy who got elected, but he wasn't really a Kennedy.
THE DISTINGUISHED GENTLEMAN - Rev. 4/3/92             32.
A lot of dead incumbents get re-elected, actually. It's an American tradition. ON Tommy. Speaking meaningfully, with great sincerity, he shows a gift for political discourse.

We ran a positive campaign. We campaigned on the issues. The issue is leadership. Leadership for the future. Ask not what you can do for your country. The people have spoken. The only thing we have to fear is fear itself. If you can't stand the heat stay out of the kitchen. Live Free or Die. And in conclusion...read my lips! (APPLAUSE and CHEERS)
Tommy looking out the window at the city below.
The approach to National Airport gives a good view of Washington and its landmarks.
sense_profile: a good view of Washington and its landmarks

text: The promised land.
The plane touches down.
Through the airport move our Floridians. They look like they're going to opening day at the track.
Congressman Johnson! Congressman Johnson! Tommy looks. It's REINHHARDT, a young straight-arrow bearing two huge document briefcases, which he puts down to shake hands.
THE DISTINGUISHED GENTLEMAN - Rev. 4/3/92              33
Arthur Reinhardt. You remember me -- I Fed-Exed that material to you in Key West?
Reinhardt, my man! Of course! You look just like I pictured you. Nice wing tips.
Thank you. Congressman, I hope you don't think I'm out of line for meeting you here -- I thought you might want some help with logistics, settling in at your hotel -- (indicating the briefcases)
Since you didn't make it to the Harvard seminar, I put together a set of their papers for you.

I like your initiative, Reinhardt, but to tell you the truth, I've never been much of a student. Maybe you can brief my staff sometime. Reinhardt looks Tommy's cronies over.     Not your classi Hill types.
But thank you, I will take you up on those logistics. Hey! Entourage! What hotel we at? They look at one another, puzzled.
Reinhardt, it appears that the staff has neglected to nail down some details.
Oh, Jesus, the IMF's in town.    Where are we going to find a room?
Four rooms.
THE DISTINGUISHED GENTLEMAN - Rev. 4/3/92              34
The entourage is enjoying a round of libations. Reinhardt runs up.
I got lucky at the Madison. Thank god there's been a coup in Uruguay. Their delegation just checked out.
You're a wizard, Reinhardt.    I knew you could handle it.
Tommy's entourage and their luggage are being packed into a cab. Tommy turns to Reinhardt.
So when does the House open for business? Reinhardt hasn't heard it put quite that way before. Reinhardt gets his courage up.
Say, Congressman, you got my resume, didn't you?
(hasn't a clue)
I'm sure I did.
There's something I wanted to ask you. I know it's a big step, but -- I'd like you to consider me to be your AA.
That's quite an offer, Reinhardt, very decent of you, but I'm just a social drinker.
No. AA. Your Administrative Assistant. I worked for Congressman Johnson. I'd like to work for you, Congressman Johnson.
Really. Tommy looks at his own troops, then back to Reinhardt.
THE DISTINGUISHED GENTLEMAN - Rev. 4/3/92            35.
You mean like an affirmative action thing? Tommy opens the cab door.
Tell you what -- I'll think about it, okay? Tommy gets in and closes the door.
(through the open window)
Thanks for getting us settled, really appreciate it. (to driver)
Madison Hotel.
The bridge over the Potomac has a classic view of the Lincoln Memorial and the Washington Monument. Their taxi drives by.
Morning. Tommy and cronies get out of a cab and bound up the grand flight of stairs. In b.g., the Capitol dome.

They walk the superb ground floor corridor of Cannon, salivating. Marble columns... chandeliers... grand offices. Real class. AT AN ELEVATOR with a sign above it -- MEMBERS ONLY -- they stop. Tommy presses the button. The door opens. The seated ATTENDANT gets a load of this group. Especially Loretta.
Sorry, folks, this elevator's for Members only.
THE DISTINGUISHED GENTLEMAN - Rev. 4/3/92             36.
That's okay, they're with me. Sixth floor please. Cannon 609. I'm going to my office.
I said Members only.
I am a Member. Now take us to six before I haul your ass in front of the committee on disrespectful behavior.
Elevator don't go to six. You have to get off at five and walk.
Looking puzzled, they make their way up a drab stairwell.
sense_profile: their way up a drab stairwell

text: Not classy. On one side of the hallway, the windows give out on a brutally ugly courtyard. On the other side of the hall are cages: windowless storage bins behind metal fences crammed with junk -- and an occasional xerox machine, Mr. Coffee, and pitiful staffer at a tiny desk. Tommy opens the door to 609.
Tommy's office is a small, dark garret, with dirty car- peting, bare shelves, and a pile of bulging canvas U.S. Mail bags.
Wait here. He heads further into the office.
Equally unattractive.   Perched on the desk:   Reinhardt.
You again!
Good morning, congressman.
What is this shithole?
THE DISTINGUISHED GENTLEMAN - Rev. 4/3/92             37.
Excuse me?
(gesturing, peeved)
This.
(casual)
Oh -- you missed the freshman   lottery for offices. They assign them    by draw. You didn't show for the    draw, so you got the worst office in   Congress.
I missed what lottery?
It was all in the briefing books I mailed you.
What else did I miss, Reinhardt?
Are you hiring me, congressman? Tommy gives Reinhardt a good once-over, seeing him anew.
You're shaking me down, aren't you? Tommy laughs, then clasps Reinhardt's shoulders.

This is fantastic, Reinhardt. I haven't been here five minutes, and you're shaking me down. God, I'm gonna love this town. You're hired, man. Just tell me what to do next. I don't want to miss out on any of the good shit.
The dinner for new Members is tonight, at Union Station. Do you have black tie? BEGIN elegant, spirited classical MUSIC.
With its hundred-foot barrel-vaulted ceiling and grand windows, the magnificent Beaux-Arts station has been beautifully restored.
THE DISTINGUISHED GENTLEMAN - Rev. 4/3/92             38.

A big crowd slowly makes its way along a red carpet to the party. Tommy was born to wear a  tux. In his  lapel, a red-and- gold eagle pin. On his   arm, Loretta, in a dramatic shoulderless and nearly  backless gown, with three-quarte gloves. The other Women   in sight are far more conserva- tively dressed.
sense_profile: its way along a red carpet

text: A STRING QUARTET provides the music. Tommy and Loretta linger uncertainly near the entrance. Then:
Let's meet some natives. Tommy leads her over to two Men, 30s, excellent haircuts. Both wear pins. He extends a hand.
Tommy Johnson, how'd you do, nice party, heck of a railroad station, isn't it?
Rafe Simon, freshman from Tulsa. And this is Bo Chandler --
-- from Lufkin, Texas. You must be the one who didn't come to Harvard.
No, I couldn't, it was my Princeton reunion....
Jeff Johnson? You're Jeff Johnson? The guy from Florida?
That's right.
(to Bo)
The rest of us are out there on the campaign trail, raising money, kissing ass, making speeches, dragging our butts from place to place -- and he slides in on pure name recognition!
THE DISTINGUISHED GENTLEMAN - Rev. 4/3/92            39.
He puts his face close to Tommy.
Let me tell you something, Jeff. A tense beat.   Then Rafe breaks into a smile.
Fuckin' brilliant. Bo winks at Tommy. Tommy
Thank you. Thank you both very much. (to Loretta)
Isn't that nice, now, don't you think? (to Rafe and Bo)
This is Miss Loretta, boys. She extends a regal hand to each, Liza Doolittle at the ball.
How do yo do.    How do you do.
And it's Tommy. My friends call me Tommy. "Jeff" is my... professional name. So what line of work were you boys in before you got elected? You lawyers or something?
Oh, no, I did morning weather and traffic for KTOK in Tulsa.
You don't remember me? I was a tight end for the Oilers -- my knee gimped out. The origins of the gentlemen's political success is not lost on Tommy.
Hey, stop by my reception after the swearing in tomorrow, okay?
Yeah, but don't you go to his reception before you go to my reception.
THE DISTINGUISHED GENTLEMAN - Rev. 4/3/92            40.
Fine, but I'm gonna be real offended if either of you miss my reception. They leave.
I think we have to have a reception. AT THE BUFFET, as Tommy and Loretta help themselves generously to oysters and champagne, they overhear TWO MEMBERS passing by.
So then I ran an ad calling him a draft dodger, but then he ran an ad calling me a plagiarist.
What did you do?
Oh, leaked a rumor that his father- in-law was a Nazi. I went up ten points in a weekend.
(to Loretta)
We're in the majors, doll. 62A   THE BALCONY is full of people working one another. Tommy and Loretta pass some large stone statues, a man extends his hand -- liquor lobbyist KEN KORNGOLD.
Congressman? I'd like to introduce myself. Ken Korngold. National Distilled Spirits Association.
Tommy Johnson. Distilled Spirits, is that right?
It's super that you won, congressman. Any way we can help, please don't hesitate.
Pleasure's all mine, Ken, hope you can make it to my reception. Do you happen to have a card?
THE DISTINGUISHED GENTLEMAN - Rev. 4/3/92             41.
(giving him one)
I sure do.
Tommy is along a wall where other guests are similarly occupied.
You now what I love about this place? The way everyone calls you a Member.  Every time I hear that, it makes me think of Mr. Happy here. The Member next to him bursts out laughing.
Don't you be peeing on my shoe. They go to the sinks.    The Member introduces himself.
Mike Strangland. Iowa -- first CD.
You got a CD?    Shit, I missed that, too.
First Congressional district.
Ohhh. Tommy Johnson. Florida. So Iowa -- how'd you get to Washington? You do the crop report on tv? IOWA has a big open face and a flat Midwestern voice.
No -- I owe it all to the Vietnamese.
War hero?
P.O.W. When I got back to Cedar Rapids, I spent so many years telling the Rotary Club what was wrong in Washington, they finally told me to put up or shut up -- so I put up. And here I am.
THE DISTINGUISHED GENTLEMAN - Rev. 4/3/92              42
Wait a minute. What's wrong in Washington?
C'mon -- there's acid rain killing fish, and no one's stopping it... there's topsoil washing away, and no erosion program... there's chemicals in our livestock -- God, I sound like a Boy Scout.
That's alright, Iowa -- this place could use a few geeks like you.
Tommy shakes hands around the table, taking business cards as he goes.
Pete Slocum.   Asbestos Information Institute.
Mike Gustofson. Freedom to Advertise Coalition.
Paul Zeckhauser. American Tobacco Council.

Hey... thank you... nice to see you... hope you can make it to my reception. Have y'all met Miss Loretta? TOMMY'S TABLEMATE is lawyer-lobbyist TOMMY O'CONNOR, 40s. As Waiters serve lobster bisque, he hands TJ a business card.
Tommy O'Connor. Soon as I saw how you got elected, I knew you were a real comer. Hell, I bet old Olaf Andersen voted for you.
Who's Olaf Andersen?
THE DISTINGUISHED GENTLEMAN - Rev. 4/3/92             43.
O'Connor points.    ON THE DAIS, Andersen is engrossed wi Dodge.
I won't tell him you asked. Chairman of Gulf Coast Power. Constituent of yours, client of mine.

Pays the rent, know what I    mean? Say, could I host a little    welcome- to-Washington thing for you    down at my law firm? Meet some of     my clients, five hundred a head -- you    could pick up twenty, twenty-five    grand to get you started.
(cautious)
And how much of that do you get?
(amused)
Oh,    it doesn't come off the top. Down    the road, I'll bill 'em each five    hundred an hour whenever I take    you to lunch.
Tommy, I think this is the beginning of a beautiful relationship.
making a speech from the dais.

Tonight we unite the two great pillars of our system -- political and financial. To the forty-four newly-elected Members of Congress, I say, Look around you tonight. Look around, and be thankful for the generosity. Tommy inspects the sea of barracudas.
THE DISTINGUISHED GENTLEMAN - Rev. 4/3/92            44.

The people you see not only provided tonight's hospitality. They are the people you serve. That's our system of checks and balances at its best. Their support helped get you elected... your work will help them... and their support will help you in your next campaign, which I remind you is already less than two years away.
In b.g., the Capitol dome. As Tommy and Loretta leave, they pass Dick Dodge, who is saying goodnight to guests. He stops them.
You know, Mr. Johnson, it's customary for new Members to pay a courtesy call on the old fogies in the leadership. Especially from their HOME STATE.
Well, I would have, but I just got to town. It's an honor to meet you, sir. A real privilege. This is Miss Loretta.
Public liaison. She pronounces the word so carefully, it sounds lewd.
How do you    do? (to    Tommy)
You could    make up for it by having a nightcap    with me. (to    Loretta)
sense_profile: by having a nightcap with me

text: May I have    my car take you home?
Tommy and Dodge walk up steps toward the Capitol.
A darkened hallway. A hand-lettered sign by a door reads COMMITTEE ON POWER AND INDUSTRY. THE CHAIRMAN. MR. DODGE. Tommy and Dodge approach. As Dodge unlocks the door:
sense_profile: A hand - lettered sign by a door

text: THE DISTINGUISHED GENTLEMAN - Rev. 4/3/92            45.
Excuse me, Mr. Chairman, but this ain't no homo shit we up to, is it?
No.  No, it's not. But -- (amused)
Good thinking, Johnson. I'm impressed by your instincts.

A single table lamp lights Dick Dodge's office, reflectin off the velvet drapes, sculpted ceiling, and crystal chandeliers. Tommy and Dodge are in leather armchairs, ties undone. On the table between them, a bottle of Jim Beam. Dodge casts a cool eye on Tommy.
Tell me, Johnson. Why did you come to Washington?
Well... of course... it's a chance to do something for my country. I mean, there's the topsoil thing, and acid rain is killing the cattle --
Cut the bullshit, Johnson. I saw how you got elected. Flukes like you are either nutcases or troublemakers. I just want to know which one I have on my hands. Who sent you here?
No one sent me.
You pulled off that upset on your own?
(acknowledging modestly)
Kid's got his talents.
I'm impressed, Johnson, I am.     But why did you run for Congress?
No bullshit?
THE DISTINGUISHED GENTLEMAN - Rev. 4/3/92              46
No bullshit.
Opportunity knocks.    This town is the fuckin' Yukon. A stunned silence from Dodge -- then deep and generous laughter.
What a refreshing answer. He laughs again, richly amused.   Tommy joins in the laughter.
Shining in the bright sun.
Hundreds of business cards. An expert riffle, a one- handed cut, and Tommy deals lightning fast, a perfect diamond formation with two cards in the middle. He turns them over one at a time.
Food... drinks.
(reads card)
Ken Korngold, National Distilled Spirits Association. Bob Rafferty ...Wisconsin Cheese Board. (to Tommy)
What do you want me to do?
You're on cheese. I'll handle booze. He reaches for the phone...
Pan from Capitol Hill to gleaming glass office building.
(taking the phone)
Ken! Ken Korngold! Tommy Johnson here... Right -- last night. How's it going, big guy?
Congressman! THE DISTINGUISHED GENTLEMAN - Rev. 4/3/92            47.
Expensive furniture, rugs, and art.
How are you on this helluva fine day! I'm looking forward to your reception.
Actually, that's why I'm calling, Ken. You said if I needed some help --
You name it, congressman. Issue papers, testimony, floor speeches --

Tell you what I have in mind. I was just thinking, wouldn't it be a plus for old Ken Korngold if I was to -- how should I put this -- showcase some of his distillers' products at my reception? You know, like they put Reese's pieces in E.T.? It's called "product placement." People come in, they have a tremendous time, they see your products, they think well of you -- and they think well of me, too. It's good for both of us, Ken. What do you say?
Well, it's a new one on me, but hey, sure, I think we can help you out.  Say, while I have you on the line, there was one thing...
The SPEAKER administers the oath of office to the assembled House.

Do you solemnly swear that you will support and defend the Constitution of the United States... ON GRANDMA next to Tommy, eyes welling with pride. It's the one day a year that non-Members (meaning families) can be on the floor.
THE DISTINGUISHED GENTLEMAN - Rev. 4/3/92              48
... against all enemies, foreign and domestic; that you will bear true faith and allegiance to the same...
The 435 Members (with family) taking the oath, watched on C-span by Loretta, Armando, Van Dyke, and Reinhardt.
... that you take this obligation freely, without any mental reservation or purpose of evasion...
ON IOWA taking the oath, his toddler in his arms.     PAN along faces of other Members... to Tommy.
... and that you will well and faithfully discharge the duties of the office on which you are about to enter. So help you God?
I do.
Congratulations. You are now Members of Congress. Sustained APPLAUSE.   Tommy kisses Grandma. INTERCUT Tommy's cronies APPLAUDING. ON THE FLOOR Tommy dries Grandma's tears with a finger.

It's just that -- I'm so happy you straightened out. Tommy smiles ambiguously. As APPLAUSE continues, his eyes roam the room and make contact with Dick Dodge, standing at one of the leadership tables. Tommy winks conspiratorially at him. There's such diabolical glee in it, it even takes Dodge aback.
A beautiful black woman, 20s, walks briskly down the busy Cannon corridors. CELIA. There's intelligence in her eyes, and fire.
THE DISTINGUISHED GENTLEMAN - Rev. 4/3/92            49.
She makes her way down the corridor, exchanging AD LIB greetings, glancing in at the sedate receptions, and drawing closer to the source of the REGGAE (O.S.) -- Tommy's office. She looks in.

It's packed, mainly with men.  Everyone has drinks and talks noisily. It looks like  a fraternity smoker for lobbyists. MUSIC comes from  a boom box. The bar -- a tablecloth over some desks -- is lavishly stocked. So are the bookcases, which now look like liquor store shelves. ANGLE ON LORETTA, in a cocktail dress and a HELLO MY NAME IS MISS LORETTA badge, staffing a little table, handing Celia a name-tag.
Celia's hands print CELIA KIRBY.    PRO BONO. BACK TO SCENE - ON Tommy and Reinhardt talking with a LOBBYIST.
It's an informal breakfast. You give us your views, we give you bacon and eggs, plus a couple of thousand dollar honorarium. (winking)
For your favorite charity. Tommy looks at Reinhardt, who explains.
The Tommy Johnson Foundation.
(savoring the word)
Honorarium. I like that. Loretta appears with a platter of food.
Herring, gentlemen?
Uh, no thanks.
Really? We've got it in cream sauce and in wine sauce.
THE DISTINGUISHED GENTLEMAN - Rev. 4/3/92            49A.
I think I'll pass. Tommy steers her aside and takes a roll of soggy, toothpick-impaled herring.
What is this?    Where's the cheese?

The cheese guy didn't return my call. So I called the guy at the American Smoked Fish Institute. She points at the food table. There's nothing but a few boxes of crackers and two huge mounds of herring -- one white, one pink. The centerpiece is a large smoked fish, eyes staring accusingly.
Oh, that's just wonderful. Sixty heavy hitters drop in, and I'm feeding 'em cat food. He breaks off, as Celia comes into view in the doorway behind. Tommy picks her up on his radar.
We'll talk about this later. We follow Tommy through the crowd until he reaches Celia.
Hi   there. Glad you could make it. So   you're... Celia Kirby. That's an   extremely beautiful name. For an   extremely beautiful woman.
Wow! That's smooth. After ten straight hours on my feet making small talk and breathing cheap cigar smoke, that's exactly the kind of line I'm ready to fall for.
Whoa, slow down.
Sure, sure, forget it. Can you just tell me, which one's Congressman Johnson?
THE DISTINGUISHED GENTLEMAN - Rev. 4/3/92            49B.
What if I said... me?
Oh. I see. So tell me, Congressman, just how deep is the shit I'm standing in? Tommy has to laugh.
Don't worry about it. Why don't we just start over again?
Celia Kirby. I'm the legislative director of Pro Bono.
Ah. Pro Bon. That's an extremely beautiful name. For an extremely beautiful organization. Um... what is it?
(amused)
We're a public interest research and advocacy group. I'd like to brief you on our priorities this session. Can I call your AA to get on your schedule?
sense_profile: to brief you on our priorities this session

text: Why don't you brief me over dinner tonight?
I want an appointment, Congressman, not a date.
Yeah, sure, we'll type it up on the schedule, it'll be an appointment, except with wine and flowers on the table.
No thanks.   I really should be going.
Won't you at least stay for a drink and some herring?
THE DISTINGUISHED GENTLEMAN - Rev. 4/3/92             49C
I'm afraid I'm busy.
Well then, can I tempt you with a smelt?
No thanks. (extending her hand)
Nice to meet you. I'll be in touch with your office. I especially look forward to hearing your view on extending the sexual harassment law to include congressmen.
I love the way you say that. She slips out through the sea of revelers.
A fine Washington morning.
Rep. ELIJAH MARSHALL, 50s, black, and a pain in Dodge's ass, is shaking hands and saying goodbye to some Constituents. Dodge approaches.
THE DISTINGUISHED GENTLEMAN - Rev. 3/25/92            50.
I heard in the steam room you're going to try to screw up my ethics bill.
Not screw up.    Amend.
Come on, Eli, your amendments don't have a chance in hell to pass. My bill isn't perfect, I know, but it'll pass. And the President'll sign it.
"Isn't perfect"? Dick, your bill's the Incumbents Protection Act! How can you even call it an ethics bill?
Because the public wants an ethics bill! So that's what we call it.
But it's got no teeth! It won't change a thing, and you know it.
Come on, Eli, you're a politician, too. The less you're going to do about something, the more you have to talk about it. You know that. They start walking.

I see. We close the bank, we stop the rubber checks, we raise the prices in the barber shop, we stop fixing parking tickets, and abracadabra! We say we've cleaned up Congress. Well, I don't think the American people want what this place has become.
That's the beauty of it! They must, Eli -- they keep re-electing us.
Not anymore! This new Congress is full of new faces.
THE DISTINGUISHED GENTLEMAN - Rev. 4/3/92            51.

Oh, I wouldn't read too much into that. A few extra retirements, some redistricting -- nothing more than that. It's still business as usual up here. Dodge takes his glasses from his pocket and wipes them.
I live in the real world, Eli. Do you? What's unemployment up to in your district? Eight percent? Eight-five?
Eight point six.
Power and Enterprise is about to fund a solar demonstration plant, Eli. It could mean a whole lot to a district -- new jobs, new construction -- that interest you?
You can't bribe me, Dick.
Dodge and Marshall enter.
Eli, the people who elected you. They sent you here to help them. Don't you want to?
Not  if it means supporting your bill. All  you want is the perfect platform to  campaign for Speaker. Dick Dodge. Mr.  Clean. What a joke!
(undeterred)
Come on board, Eli. (leaning in)
You know -- you can't save the world if you can't save your seat. Tommy enters.   Marshall gives him a once-over and extend a hand.
sense_profile: if you ca n't save your seat

text: THE DISTINGUISHED GENTLEMAN - Rev. 4/3/92            52.
We haven't met. Eli Marshall.
Tommy Johnson.
I know. The Florida upset. Well, now that you're here, what are you going to do with it? You gonna feather your own nest, or are you gonna make something of your office?
I plan to be as good a congressman as all the others.
Exactly what does that mean?
Well, ever since I got back from Nam, I've wanted to do something about the rain forest --
No, do me a favor, don't tell me. I try not to get depressed until the second week of a new session.
(ushering Tommy into his office)
Eli, you'll excuse us -- we have a meeting.
Johnson, I'm the chairman of a committee up here called Power and Industry. We've got an open seat, and I was wondering if you'd consider filling it.
Is this good news?
THE DISTINGUISHED GENTLEMAN - Rev. 4/3/92              53
(tongue in cheek)

Well, it is a difficult assignment -- look at what we cover: energy, health, telecommunications, environment... the committee is constantly beset by a swarm of special interests. These are powerful people, they've got all the money in the world, and they're not shy about using it.
So... this is very good news.
Most members would give their right nut for it.
So what do you want from me, Dick?
Congressman... I just want you to smile for the cameras.

The committee members -- all white males, except Tommy -- mill around, awaiting the start of the hearings. As the TV cameras whir, Dodge shakes Tommy's hand warmly. Big smiles and an explosion of flashbulbs. Dodge breaks off and Tommy drifts over to Reinhardt.
(indicating dais)
So, Congressman, welcome to the honey pot. You should be one happy freshman.

Yeah? Well, I'm not. I'm suspicious. One thing I've learned is, when somebody gives you something for nothing, the nothing ain't nothing. It's something. What is it? Why me? Reinhardt puts his hand on Tommy's shoulders.
THE DISTINGUISHED GENTLEMAN - Rev. 4/3/92               5
Congressman, I don't want you to take this the wrong way, but... you're black. And I mean that in the nicest possible way.
Keep talking.
Dodge wants to run for Speaker. And he ain't gonna make it without votes from the black caucus. Suddenly, Dodge reappears.   He throws his arm around Tommy's shoulders.
Tommy, someone I want you to meet... Dodge steers TJ to a preppy-looking man at the witness table -- BARCLAY "SKEETER" WARBURTON.
Skeeter, do you know Tommy Johnson? Meet the new member of the committee. Tommy, this is Barclay Warburton.
Pleased to meet you, Barclay. WARBURTON'S voice is aristocratic, a la George Plimpton.
Skeeter. Please. Been called that since boarding school.
Skeeter.
Damned fine to meet you. As Dodge and Tommy head for the dais, Tommy imitates Warburton's lockjaw.
"Tommy. Please. Been called that since reform school." Dodge chuckles, shakes his head in mock rebuke. Tommy takes his seat at the lower dais, smiles at the Members on his left and right.
THE DISTINGUISHED GENTLEMAN - Rev. 4/3/92             55.
ON THE UPPER DAIS, Dodge gavels...

This EPA oversight hearing of the Committee on Power and Industry will come to order. I'd like to welcome our first witness, the distinguished Administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency... (Warburton nods)

... but before I do, I note that a new Member is joining us today, the distinguished gentleman from Florida. THE BIGGEST EXPLOSION OF FLASHES YET... and as the motor drives whir, Tommy flashes his biggest smile yet.
sense_profile: that a new Member is joining us today , the distinguished gentleman from Florida

text: Tommy's office walls are now richly hung with plaques, awards, and framed photos. We see he has been named the PESTICIDE COALITION'S Man of the Month. The winner of the NATIONAL RIFLE ASSOCIATION'S Achievement Award. The MOTION PICTURE ASSOCIATION OF AMERICA'S Outstanding Young Legislator. Etc. The liquor is gone. Loretta is at the receptionist's desk.   A LOBBYIST enters.
sense_profile: he has been named the PESTICIDE COALITION 'S Man of the Month

text: Morning. Ron Yaeger. Snack-PAC -- Snack Foods Political Action Committee. I have a ten o'clock.
Please have a seat. The congressman is running just a little bit late. He sits and opens his briefcase. Van Dyke approaches him with the dignity of a superb butler.
Would you care for some herring?
Tommy rises to speak at a breakfast meeting. The podium bears the seal of the American Poultry Association.
sense_profile: to speak at a breakfast meeting

text: THE DISTINGUISHED GENTLEMAN - Rev. 4/3/92            56.

Let me start with a confession. I don't know much about poultry. But I do know something about people. And let me tell you: I like you people. So when you have something to say about poultry, I listen. Thank you very much. He sits down to generous APPLAUSE. ON Armando, in attendance, CLAPPING, marveling at the response TJ gets.

Capitol Hill is actually two worlds: the aboveground buildings that visitors and television cameras see, and the catacombs, the busy tunnels and corridors connecting the congressional office buildings and the Capitol. They're surprisingly unglamorous -- exposed pipes, white- washed brick walls, dumpsters, pizza carry-outs -- and through them move the legislators and their staffs. And here is Tommy, whistling ZIPPEDY DOO DAH. He loves this place. Passing a snack bar, he greets the Cashier.
My man. He blows a kiss to a pretty Teller in the credit union. Passing the barber shop, he calls out to the Shoeshine Guy. He passes a black TELEPHONE MAN at an open panel of wires.
Tommy!    What's up, man?
(whispering)
Sweet Sue. Third race at Santa Anita.
Several lobbyists are now awaiting Tommy balancing plates of herring on their knees. Some are enjoying it more than others. Tommy breezes in.
Hey, how you folks doin', good to see you, Van Dyke making you comfortable? Tommy hits a button on a tape deck, turning on some EASY LISTENING.
THE DISTINGUISHED GENTLEMAN - Rev. 4/3/92            57.
Be with y'all shortly. BEHIND THE DIVIDER, outside Tommy's office door, Tommy ha a word with Reinhardt. Tommy indicates his office.
She in there? Reinhardt nods.   Tommy gives himself a couple of squirts Binaca.
Stick around for this, Reinhardt. I've finally figured something out about the women in this town.
Tommy and Reinhardt meeting with Celia and an elfin guy in corduroy.
Thank you for seeing us, congressman, we won't take up much of your time. This is Ira Schecter, our research director.
Hi, good to meet you, you folks know Reinhardt, don't you? Don't rush, Miss Kirby, we can take as long as we want.
But you have people waiting, and --
That's all right. They can wait.
Well. She pulls documents from her briefcase and hands them to Tommy.

These are issue papers. This session we're targeting auto insurance premiums, child safety, and food additives.   As votes come up, we know you'll be hearing plenty from the other side. We'd just like a clean shot at making our case, too.
THE DISTINGUISHED GENTLEMAN - Rev. 4/3/92            58.
(rising)
So, we'll follow up with your staff in the next week or...
Wait a minute, you just got here. I clean my calendar, and you're out the door. Let's back up, give this stuff the attention it deserves. Car insurance... Ira, what do you pay?
Oh, I've got an '85 Plymouth, about six-fifty a year...
Six-fifty? Highway robbery! A chop shop wouldn't give you more than a hundred forty for a junker like that. (beat)
Or so I've heard. (beat)
But I'm flying blind here, I need depth. Could Miss Kirby put together a briefing? Maybe schedule a Saturday or two to really dig into the issues?
(surprised and pleased)
Oh... we'd be delighted. We've got some figures that will amaze you.
I'm sure you do.
(rising)
Well, we won't take up any more...
Whoa, whoa, hold on, what about child safety?
Well, we're sponsoring a bill imposing safety standards on imported toys...
THE DISTINGUISHED GENTLEMAN - Rev. 4/3/92               5
Great! About time! I     hate imported toys. What about food    additives? How about we block out   a few evenings, you can take   me through the details.
Celia, if that's what the Congressman wants... any problem?
(to him)
You want to do this in the evening?
sense_profile: to do this in the evening

text: I'm away for the next two weeks. She gives him a look.    Ira turns to Tommy.
So, when can Celia start your briefings?
Saturday night?
Saturday night sounds fine.
Fine. Wednesday morning.      Nine- fifteen.
On a door in the House sub-basement:    MEMBERS ONLY.
The regular evening pickup basketball game. Even among these ruthless players, Tommy's street moves are outstand ingly down and dirty. His principal accomplice: Elijah Marshall.

A standing poker game among the towel- and robe-clad Members. It's Tommy's shuffle and deal.    He is convincingly awkw A BULLDOG of a man examines his hand, tosses two cards in He assembles his new hand. Four fives and an ace.
THE DISTINGUISHED GENTLEMAN - Rev. 4/3/92               6
ON Tommy's hand.   A pair of threes. The betting starts, at a couple of chips, and comes round to Tommy. He pushes a stack of chips to the center.
Let's get serious, fellas.
Tommy, Marshall, and the Bulldog, back in suits, exit the MEMBERS ONLY door and move through the catacombs.
sense_profile: Tommy , Marshall , and the Bulldog , back in suits
Tommy , Marshall , and the Bulldog , back in suits

text: I need your help on the ethics bill, Leon. I want you to co- sponsor my amendments.
You make a persuasive case, Eli.
That wasn't a yes.
(courteously ambiguous)
I promise to give it the attention it deserves. The Bulldog gives Tommy a friendly squeeze --
sense_profile: to give it the attention it deserves

text: Better luck next time, son. -- and leaves them.   Tommy and Marshall continue on.
He took six hundred dollars off you that last hand, didn't he?
Yeah, he's taking a real shine to me.
If I didn't know better, I'd say you lost to him on purpose.
Nothing wrong with letting the chairman of the ethics committee roll you once in a while.
THE DISTINGUISHED GENTLEMAN - Rev. 4/3/92           60A.
(shaking his head)
You fit in real well up here.   Too well.
So Eli, how come you haven't asked for my help with your amendments?
Give it a rest, Tommy. You've got a great jump shot. But everyone knows you're Dick Dodge's boy.
(bristling)
I'm nobody's boy, mister.
(weary)
Don't waste your outrage on me. I know what you are.
I'm no different from anyone else.
That's not true. Some people here actually try to do something besides save their own ass.
You know, Eli, I like you, I really do. You remind me of my father.
Oh, really?   How so?

He thought I was scum, too. BELLS begin RINGING and LIGHTS FLASHING on all the clocks and sconces down the corridor. Three RINGS, pause, three RINGS, pause... Marshall does a U-turn. Tommy doesn't follow suit.
Aren't you going to vote?
(indicating clocks)
Vote? Is that what that is? We got a pool going in the office on when it'll go off next. THE DISTINGUISHED GENTLEMAN - Rev. 4/3/92            60B.

It's called "Gucci Gulch." The lobby just outside the doors to the House chamber is pandemonium -- a sea of lobbyists, lawyers, PACmen, Members, and staffers urgently trying to find their masters and signal them thumbs-up or-down. Tommy enters, sweeps the room with his eyes, looking for Reinhardt, shrugs, then goes through the doors onto the floor.
sense_profile: sweeps the room with his eyes , looking for Reinhardt , shrugs

text: Tommy goes to a console on the rear of a seat. A blue light says OPEN. Tommy inserts a card (it looks like an electronic hotel key). Red, green, and amber lights at buttons labeled NAY, YEA, and PRES. Tommy shrugs, pushes NAY.
sense_profile: to a console on the rear of a seat
at buttons labeled NAY , YEA , and PRES. Tommy

text: As Tommy heads away, he passes a class trip -- a dozen fifth-graders and their TEACHER, who hails him.

Excuse me -- Congressman? Do you have a moment? We're from the Hawthorne Avenue School, in Union, New Jersey? I'm Mrs. Kozlowski. Social Studies. We were just learning how a bill becomes a law. (indicating the BELLS)
Was that a vote?
Yes, it was.
And what did you vote?
I voted "Nay." It's a terrible bill. It'd destroy the fabric of American life.
And what was the vote on? Tommy hasn't a clue. He calls out to Rafe, who is among those leaving the chamber.
Hey, Rafe! Tell these kids what that vote was about.
THE DISTINGUISHED GENTLEMAN - Rev. 4/3/92             61.
(to kids)
Guy's got a real knack for explaining things.
Well, it was a motion to reconsider the motion to reconsider. Bo, passing by, intervenes.
No, it was the rule on amending the reauthorization.
Which means?
Clean Air.
(overlapping)
School lunches.
You're in excellent hands, kids.
A NOISY restaurant popular with lobbyists. Power photos on the wall. Table hopping. People SHOUTING greetings across the room. Waiters in long aprons. Tommy is having lunch with Tommy O'Connor.
You're a gentleman, Tommy. We can always do bid'ness -- I like that in a Member.
Thank you, Tommy. I love you too.
Listen, I'd like to do more money for you -- I just need to know your positions on a few issues. O'Connor takes out a pen and leather notecard case.
For instance, where are you on sugar price supports?
THE DISTINGUISHED GENTLEMAN - Rev. 4/3/92            62.
Tommy has no idea, but he's certainly open to suggestions.
Sugar price supports. Where do you think I should be, Tommy?
Shit -- makes no difference to me. If you're for 'em, I got money for you from my sugar producers in Louisiana and Hawaii. If you're against 'em, I got money for you from the candy manufacturers.
You pick.
(writing)
Let's put you down as for. Now what about putting limits on malpractice awards?
You tell me.
Well, if you're for 'em, I got money from the doctors and insurance companies. If you're against 'em, I got money from the trial lawyers. Tell you what, let's say against. Now how about pizza?
(indicating his plate)
I'll stick with the salad.
Not for lunch, shmuck, for PAC money. A lot of the frozen pizzas use phony cheese. There's a law pending requiring them to disclose it on their labels. Where do you stand? Tommy thinks it through.
If I vote for the labels...then I get money from the dairy industry...
THE DISTINGUISHED GENTLEMAN - Rev. 4/3/92          63.
Good...
And if I vote against the labels, I get money from the frozen food guys.
Excellent! And don't forget the ranchers, because they get hurt if pepperoni sales go down!
(laughing in admiration)
A pepperoni lobby. I love this town.
So which is it?
Fuck the cheese people. Thanks to them my office smelled like smelt for a week.
All right.    For.
So Tommy, tell me -- with all this money on every side, how does anything get done?
It doesn't!    That's the genius of the system!
A briefing in progress. Flip charts, ring binders, Celia, Ira, a couple of other Pro Bono types. Tommy is riveted by Celia.

It comes down to a question of what is acceptable risk. Are we willing to feed our kids a substance that causes cancer in lab rats? More important, who gets to make the decision? Bureaucrats and big corporations, or the people whose lives depend on it? THE DISTINGUISHED GENTLEMAN - Rev. 4/3/92            64.
Tommy's staff shares one small office.   Everyone's on th phone.
Mr. Willie? Congressman Johnson is calling. Can you take his call? Thank you. Please hold. Van Dyke puts him on hold, counts to three, gets back on the line.
I'm sorry, Mr. Willie, he just picked up another call. Listen, I know why he was calling -- he hasn't heard from you about his fundraiser... PAN TO Armando.
... That's right, Mr. Brown, on the thirtieth... A thousand a couple...A whole table? He'll be so happy to hear it. Thank you so much. (calling)
Loretta! Put down nuclear power for ten g's. PAN TO Loretta, who chalks the figure onto a toteboard.
Cool. (into phone)
Mr. Newburg? It's Miss Loretta, from Congressman Johnson's office, how you doin'? On Loretta's bulletin board is a map of the United States with flags, pushpins, and air travel routes.

Say, the congressman's going to be out your way next week... Palm Springs, the Bob Hope Classic -- yes, a celebrity player. As long as he's on the coast, we were wondering whether you aerospace people might want to lay on a lunch so you can hear his views... Uh-huh ... Uh-huh... Lovely. Now what kind of contribution to his foundation you folks thinking about? THE DISTINGUISHED GENTLEMAN - Rev. 4/3/92              65
Celia continues her briefing.
...And in the 1988 study, it was up to eight per hundred-thousand. Um...am I losing you on these mortality rates?
No, I was just wondering how much of this is a statutory problem, and how much is a regulatory one? I mean, didn't the Merton Act cover most of this?
(surprised)

Hmmm, that's an excellent point. Let me see something... As she starts rummaging in her briefcase, we TRACK AROUND to a COMPUTER SCREEN on Tommy's desk -- it displays THE EXACT WORDS HE'S JUST SPOKEN.

Wow...you're right. Maybe we can get them to amend Merton-Simmons. RACK FOCUS...reveals REINHARDT in b.g., sitting at another computer terminal. He is typing in Tommy's responses, which appear on Tommy's screen.

Well, for Merton to apply you have to show high contagion...sounds to me like your contagion rates are no higher than the common clod. In b.g., Reinhardt DIVES FORWARD to his keyboard and begins correcting his typo. Celia looks puzzled.
Common cold. (beat)
Must have picked up a little dyslexia over the weekend.
I see. Well, I must say I'm pretty impressed.
You're also impressively pretty.
THE DISTINGUISHED GENTLEMAN - Rev. 4/3/92           66.
Celia is startled. Tommy is embarrassed...the dumb compliment he's just spoken was one Reinhardt typed on the computer screen.
Oh come on...
You're right. Sorry.      Excuse me a second. (calls out)
Arthur? Without explanation, he THROWS HIS PENCIL hard out of frame.
Ow!
A jet flies through the sky.
Tommy and handful of other Members listen to their GUN LOBBYIST host.
sense_profile: Tommy and handful of other Members

text: Frankly, we    think the semi-automatic has gotten a    bad rap. That's why the American    Sporting Gun Users PAC put together    this trip. ON TOMMY AND DODGE enjoying champagne and hors d'oeuvres.

Tommy, wearing full L.L. Bean drag, wading with the other Members. Someone blows a shrieking DUCK CALL. A flock takes flight Everyone in the group raises their weapons: AK-47s. A burst of GUNFIRE. Rambo time. We SEE the flock still flying. One duck drops at the feet of the hunters.
