sense_profile: at the feet of the hunters

text: Must have had a heart attack. THE DISTINGUISHED GENTLEMAN - Rev. 4/3/92              67

Tommy tees off. He is wearing a veritable pro     shop of custom golf gear, all emblazoned with logos of    corpora sponsors and lobbies. He hits the ball about     200 yards...but more or less perpendicular to the    hole. REVEAL BOB HOPE standing nearby, watching.
I knew all these congressmen get a slice, but I didn't know it was that big.
Tommy on the phone.
Did you miss me?
Celia at her desk in the somewhat ratty Pro Bono offices.
Where did you go?
Oh, a fact-finding mission, some issue conferences, a few speaking engagements, a charity event... the usual.
More like the Petroleum Institute Ski Cup, the NRA Open, the --
Hey.    Have lunch with me tomorrow.
I can't -- we're having a press conference.
What is it -- the ozone layer?     No fault? Killer apples?
THE DISTINGUISHED GENTLEMAN - Rev. 4/3/92            68.
(laughing)
Toy safety. Wait a minute. Tomorrow's Friday. Aren't you back early?
(beaming)
You remembered! That means you missed me.
Tommy and Celia walk over the bridge to the cherry trees by the Tidal Basin.
So, how'd you end up hustling for Pro Bono instead of pesticides? I mean, you could have been a big- time lawyer, right?
Oh, I was for a while.   It... depressed me.
At a hundred grand a year, how depressed can you get? Doesn't it depress you to lose all the time?
Sometimes. Mostly it gets me angry. And the anger keeps me going. Sure, I wouldn't mind winning a few. And it's not like I'm allergic to money...
So why do you do it? She skips a stone on the water.
God, it's so embarrassing to come out and say it.
Say it.
Meaning. I need my life to mean something.
THE DISTINGUISHED GENTLEMAN - Rev. 4/3/92               6
This actually hits Tommy.    Celia, embarrassed, changes the subject.
My question is, how'd you get named after a Memorial?
Grandma like Jefferson. Y'know, "Life, liberty and the pursuit of happiness." It's a lot to live up to, so I specialized in the last part.
And how's the pursuit going?
Fine...'til I met you. Now...the better I do, the worse I feel. They have stopped walking.    They are standing close together. They kiss.
So...when can I see you again? How about dinner Saturday night? She shakes her head.
How about Sunday morning?
Brunch?
In the pulpit, Rev. Elijah Marshall thunders:

The wages of sin is death! And to the man who values Gold over Goodness...the Lord allows no exemptions! REVEAL TOMMY and Celia in the front pew. Marshall appears to be preaching directly to Tommy, who wears a slightly sick smile.
To the man who shows no respect for the privilege of walking this Earth, God allows no deductions!
THE DISTINGUISHED GENTLEMAN - Rev. 4/3/92            70.
(AMEN)
And to the man whose pockets are bulging and whose soul is empty... the Lord grants no 90-day extension! (AMEN)
And when the last trump sounds, believe me, you will be audited!
(aside to Celia)
This is one hell of a date.
On the steps, Marshall shakes hands with his Congregants. Tommy and Celia exit the church. Marshall takes Celia by the hands and kisses her familiarly. Tommy is taken aback.
Hello, darling. Glad you could make it.
I liked the sermon, Uncle Eli.
Uncle Eli?
My niece says you're not half as slimy as I thought.
Your niece?
That would put you somewhere between a lizard and a toad. Quite a step up. Tommy looks from Marshall to Celia and back again.
How could I have missed the family resemblance?
WHISTLING happily, Tommy rounds the corner and heads to his office.
THE DISTINGUISHED GENTLEMAN - Rev. 4/3/92           71.
Ahead of him, encamped in the hallway, he sees a phalanx of SENIOR CITIZENS, many carrying placards, and some camera crews. Tommy adjusts his tie, turns on the charm, and approaches.
sense_profile: a phalanx of SENIOR CITIZENS , many carrying placards , and some camera crews

text: Ladies! Looking good!   How can I help you folks today! But Hattie Rifkin and her troops will have none of it.
Don't "Ladies!" me, you dick! The camera lights go on.
Now let me get this straight. You voted to make people on Medicare pay more money to their doctors?
The Medical Association made a persuasive case. Ten grand from their PAC, plus Christmas in Aspen.
(shaking his head)

Tommy -- if I'm not mistaken, you wouldn't be here without the good senior citizens of your district. You got to dance with the girl that brung you, son. If you have a bit of business to do, do it quietly... in the corridors... in the subcommittees... with little amendments. You mess around on the big ones like Medicare, you'll be dead meat on election day.
Yeah, well, then it's thanks for the memories, and on to the next gig.
Do you know what your problem is, son? You don't think big enough. You have a real knack for this town, but you have the soul of a two-bit hustler. Listen to me, Tommy.
THE DISTINGUISHED GENTLEMAN - Rev. 4/3/92            72.

Five hundred thirty-five Members of Congress. Some are smart, and some stupid. Some good, some not. But all of them, son, all of them consumed by the single overriding imperative that defines the very Washington way of life.
Which is?
Getting re-elected.
Wait a minute. You're talkin' 'bout my re-election?
You don't know what percent of the incumbents who ran last time got re-elected, do you?
Fifty?   Sixty?

Ninety-six. And ninety-eight before that. It's like that election after election. If you don't fuck up, you can be here, raking it in, for life. Life, Johnson. Tommy considers this.   Then a big smile.
I can think of worse places to get life.
(smiles)
I knew you had it in you.
So how do I get the Silver Foxes off my ass?
Oh, throw them a bone... why don't you co-sponsor a bill for mandatory universal health insurance?
THE DISTINGUISHED GENTLEMAN - Rev. 4/3/92            73.
What's that mean?
Nothing.   It'll never pass.
A couple of Lobbyists await Tommy. Van Dyke mans the desk. In come ELLEN JUBA, 40s, and her 13-year-old daughter, MICKEY, whose pony tail sticks out from her Florida Marlins baseball cap.
sense_profile: from her Florida Marlins baseball cap

text: May I help you?
Yes, I'm Ellen Juba. This is my daughter, Mickey. We'd like to see our congressman. We live in the district.
Just a moment, please. (dials; into phone)
Could you come out? Thank you. (hanging up)
Be right with you. (to Mickey)
I like your hat. Loretta comes out and extends a hand.
How do you do, I'm Miss Loretta, public liaison for the congressman.
Ellen Juba. My daughter Mickey. We'd like to see him.

Y'all from the district? Up    here seein' the sights? How'd you    folks like some gallery passes? Go    on over and listen to the great   debates of our day? She reaches into Van Dyke's desk drawer to get some passe
We don't want to go to the gallery. We want to see Congressman Johnson.
THE DISTINGUISHED GENTLEMAN - Rev. 4/3/92            74.
How 'bout a House key ring for each of you? Here -- see that? Isn't that something? Turns into a pen.
You don't understand. We're not tourists. We're constitutents.
(helpfully)
You aren't with some organization, are you, honey?
I'm a goddam citizen! Isn't that enough!
We're not leaving here till we see him! Loretta exchanges a look with the Lobbyists, who get the picture. She picks up the phone and speaks nonchalantly.
Oh, Armando? Could you come out front, please? Tommy enters, carrying an enormous tennis trophy.
Look what I won! Must be that new racket. Armando has come out to hear this.
There a problem, congressman?
Congressman?   You? Armando tries to escort her out.
Get your hands off me! Mickey tries to block Armando.
Let go of her, you creep!
THE DISTINGUISHED GENTLEMAN - Rev. 4/3/92
Careful, she may be armed!

Stop it!     Get away from her! Armando, defending himself from Mickey, manages to knock her hat off. With the hat comes her (apparently false) pony tail. ON MICKEY.   She's bald.    Her skull bears the mark of s Everyone stops.    It's quiet. Mickey's eyes burn into Tommy's.        Then she picks up hat.
Come on, Ma.      It's okay.    Let's go.
Wait.     What happened to you?
Not just me.
Tommy and his staff listen to the Jubas.
I was lucky. They said they got it all. I'm going to be okay. But what about the others?
The others?

They call it a "cancer cluster." Oh, at first, none of us in the neighborhood wanted to believe it, but then we all saw it -- for me, it was when the two-year-old across the street developed a brain tumor, same as Mickey. We looked at everything -- the water, the air, dump sites, insects, you name it. But we didn't have to look that far. It was staring us in the face.
What?
THE DISTINGUISHED GENTLEMAN - Rev. 4/3/92            76.
Power lines.
High-voltage power lines. The wires cause magnetic fields -- and the magnetic fields cause cancer. Especially in children.
I never heard of that. Mickey pulls a stack of journals and xeroxes from her book bag and gives it to her mother, who in turn gives the materials to Tommy.
The studies, the numbers -- it's all there.
(to Tommy, skeptical)
You're not actually going to read those, are you?
(caught)
Oh, they'll be read...
Why don't you come see for yourself? Tommy has no quick answer.

Children playing on swings and seesaws in a small public park. TILT UP. A pair of electric power derricks carrying 225,000-volt lines almost directly overhead. The derricks cast shadows across a nearby school. We SEE the neighborhood. Quite a few FOR SALE signs. A house with a moving sale in progress on the front lawn. ON Tommy taking it all in.   With him are Celia and the Jubas.
Five children   in the neighborhood have cancer.    One more has precancerous   lesions. Pregnant women around   here are scared to death.
THE DISTINGUISHED GENTLEMAN - Rev. 4/3/92            77.
This is Mickey's school?
Turns out a lot of schools are near power lines. The land's cheap, so the schools tend to buy it from the power companies in the first place.
But isn't the school district responsible?
We asked the superintendent to measure the magnetic field inside the school. He said, Okay, only it'll cost forty thousand dollars, and what program did we want him to cut that from?
Nice.
We're nobody, congressman. You're somebody. We need your help. Tommy takes Celia aside.
Do you believe it?
It's impossible to know. No one's really looked into it hard enough.
But why isn't it being investigated?
Why didn't they investigate breast implants all those years? What about those side-effects of that sleeping pill, Halcion? Why isn't anything being investigated? It's always the same.
Money talks.
You got it.
THE DISTINGUISHED GENTLEMAN - Rev. 4/3/92             78.
There must be something I can do for those people.
Don't tell me you're actually developing a conscience.
Shit, I hope not -- it'd be a fucking nuisance in Congress.
No, that's not fair. Some people on the Hill actually believe in things, and try to do a decent job, and don't forget why they went to Washington, and who sent them.
(amazed)
No shit. (remembering)
Oh, yeah, I met one of those geeks. So what can I do?

Make a stink. Round up some Members and hold a press conference. Get that committee of yours to hold hearings. Haul in in the Environmental Protection Agency, the Surgeon General, the National Academy of Sciences. Get the issue on every breakfast table in America.

A press conference. Half a dozen congressmen, Tommy among them. Iowa is speaking to the few Cameras and Reporters. Beside him, Mickey Juba and her mother. Reinhardt and Ceila among the handful of staff and onlookers.
This goes beyond personal tragedy. It goes to a public health hazard of unknown proportions. It goes to the right of ordinary people to know all the facts --
THE DISTINGUISHED GENTLEMAN - Rev. 4/3/92              79
Yeah, right -- people ought to know if their neighborhoods are killing them.
Amen, gentleman. Amen. They turn, somewhat surprised to see Dick Dodge, who joins Iowa at the microphones, a natural leader.
What a fine effort this is. I am totally sympathetic. Congressional hearings should be scheduled as soon as possible. The American people deserve no less. He puts an arm around Mickey.
Message:   we care.
Tommy and Celia are watching the press conference on TV.
Well, congratulations. You've found yourself your own hopeless cause.
Speaking of hopeless causes... They kiss, and slide OUT OF FRAME.
An impressive THUNDERSTORM pounds on Dodge's windows.
(pouring)
On the rocks, or neat?
Whatever you're having.
THE DISTINGUISHED GENTLEMAN - Rev. 4/3/92            80.
Well, why ruin good bourbon with the taste of some shitty Sears icemaker, that's what I always say. (handing Tommy a glass)
Cheers.
Cheers. Dodge downs his drink.   Tommy follows suit.
Son, you're a real comer. I wouldn't be surprised if you ended up in the leadership. I'll say this: if I were Speaker, I'd sleep better with you as a lieutenant.
Why, thank you, Mr. Chairman. You know, to tell you the truth, I didn't know you'd be on my side on those power lines.
But I'm not.
But you said you were sympathetic --
Of course I did. We're all sympathetic to little girls with cancer. But I'm not sympathetic to holding an inquiry.
But you said --
I know what I said. But that was just a press conference, son. I wasn't under oath. The intercom BUZZES.
(into phone)
Yes?... Bring them right in! (hanging up)
Look. Son. It's great to get your name in the paper.
THE DISTINGUISHED GENTLEMAN - Rev. 4/3/92             81.

I bet the gentleman from Iowa was all over the evening news in Des Moines tonight. Getting good press -- letting them know you care -- that's what it's all about. Smart move, Tommy. But that's as far as I'd go with this, if I were you. The door opens. Dodge turns to see Olaf Anderson, Tommy O'Connor, and Zeke Bridges enter.
What a surprise!
Mr. Chairman!
Mr. Chairman! Hello, Tommy. Zeke you're looking well, good to see you.
(wheezing)
Good to see you, you old sum' bitch.
Evening, Mr. Chairman, thanks for taking the -- Tommy, you s.o.b., they let you in here? (indicating Andersen and Bridges)
You folks finally get to press flesh! Olaf, meet Tommy Johnson. Tommy, Olaf Andersen. Chairman of Gulf Coast Power.
The boys here have told me a lot about you.
Yeah -- I told him you voted for him! They all share a laugh.    Except for Bridges, who squint at Tommy.
Glad to meet you, son. They tell me you've got a real talent for the game.
THE DISTINGUISHED GENTLEMAN - Rev. 4/3/92            81A.
And this is Zeke Bridges, CEO of Pyramid Insurance.
(still puzzling)
Congressman.
Good to meet you.
Help me with these, would you, Tommy? He hands Tommy a couple of drinks.
(to Zeke)
Chivas on the rocks?
(taking the drink)
You look awfully familiar. Tommy just smiles.
Tommy and I were just talking about power lines.
Yeah, what a coincidence. I thought this little party might be for me. (to Anderson)
You may not like this. (to Dodge)
I think we should hold those hearings.
You really fell for the line that parents group fed you, didn't you? Tommy is struck by Dodge's intelligence.
How'd you know I met the parents group?
THE DISTINGUISHED GENTLEMAN - Rev. 4/3/92            81B.
Oh, I keep my ear to the ground, that's what a good politician does. Listen, Tommy, why don't we just get Olaf's take on this.

It's tragic, cancer's a terrible thing, but there's no way you can link it to power lines. Truth is, there's a bigger electromagnetic field given off by an electric blanket, or a microwave oven, than by those derricks.
But there are studies that say --
For every study that says one thing, I'll show you a study saying another. We've studied it ourselves. Nada.
There's not a single state health official anywhere in this country who says power lines cause cancer.
But what if you're wrong? As Tommy persists, Andersen looks increasingly angry.
People didn't use to say smoking causes cancer, either. What if the evidence is just building, and some day we wake up and discover that your power lines are killing us?
(exploding)
"Kill  us"? "Kill us"? You calling me a  murderer? You're saying there's blood  on these hands? How dare you talk  to me like that, you -- O'Connor puts a restraining arm on Andersen.
sense_profile: you talk to me like that , you

text: Calm down, Olaf, calm down, he didn't mean it that way, did you, son? Alright, gentlemen. Easy.
THE DISTINGUISHED GENTLEMAN - Rev. 4/3/92             82.
Andersen backs off, regains his composure.    The outburs makes an impression on Tommy. Tommy
I'm just saying, it's worth looking into.

Tommy -- do you want to move the power lines? Do you know how much it would cost to bury them? Millions. Tens of millions. I don't have that money. The state doesn't have that money. You people up here sure don't have that money. You know who'd end up paying for it? Folks who sent you here, that's who.
Now how'd you like the   people in your district to think   of you as the putz who tripled their   electric bill? You think they'd thank   you for that on election day?
All I'm saying is, maybe we should hold hearings to look at --
Think for a minute, boychik. You hold your hearings. Overnight, everyone who lives near a substation finds the value of his home in the toilet. You kill the real estate market.
You kill the insurance companies.
You kill the school district.
You kill the local economy.
For a smart boy, you're not thinking very politically. Tommy watches the LIGHTNING.
Maybe I should think about it.
THE DISTINGUISHED GENTLEMAN - Rev. 4/3/92             83.
Yeah, the system ain't perfect, but the fleas come with the dawg.

Oh, by the    way, Tommy, on a completely different    subject -- You don't have a state PAC    yet, do you? I'd like to give you a    hundred thousand dollar corporate    contribution to start one up.
My company would be honored to do the same.
Can you do that?     I thought there were limits --
Oh, it's all aboveboard, we all believe deeply in the rules. It's just that the state rules are often more flexible about these things.
Are you interested?
I'm always interested in the happiness of my constituents.
I'll drink to that. Dodge and Andersen shoot each other a look.
Tommy pulls up in a Corvette with Florida congressional plates in front of his Capitol Hill row house.
sense_profile: in a Corvette with Florida congressional plates

text: Tommy slips into bed next to Celia, who's half asleep.
Mmmm...
THE DISTINGUISHED GENTLEMAN - Rev. 4/3/92            84.
Mmmm...
So what did he say?
Who?
Dodge.    The hearings.
Oh -- I, uh, haven't asked him yet. Celia suddenly looks quite awake.
(casual)
It wasn't the right moment. Besides, I was thinking, maybe I ought to line up some other Members first -- you know, get my ducks in a row.
sense_profile: to line up some other Members first

text: Oh.
Dick Dodge and several other towel-clad MEMBERS.
You see that ABC poll?
Free fall.
President in trouble like that, he's liable to do something desperate. Some damn fool stunt.
Invade Japan.
Declare war on Congress, more like it.
THE DISTINGUISHED GENTLEMAN - Rev. 3/25/92             85
The door opens.     Eli Marshall, fully dressed, comes in
You shafted me on the ethics bill.
THE DISTINGUISHED GENTLEMAN - Rev. 4/3/92            86.
Hello, Eli, good to see you.   Why don't you loosen your tie?
It's a closed rule. I can't get my amendments on the floor. I can't get a recorded vote. I can't get squat.
Last time I looked, it was the Rules Committee in charge of that. This isn't the Rules Committee, Eli. This is the steam room.
This is the U.S. Congress! The American people deserve better than --
You know what your problem is, Eli? You've got sermonitis. The other Members chuckle.
Can't open your mouth without climbing into the pulpit, can you? Why don't you just calm down, have a massage --
I've got news for you, Dick. I'm going to run against you for Speaker. I may not have a rat's ass of a chance to beat you. But I sure as hell can tell the world the kind of sleaze you stand for.
I went too far with him, I know it. You know him pretty well, don't you?
Oh, I don't know...
Come on, you play basketball together, you're seeing his niece, you've been to his church --
How did you know that?
THE DISTINGUISHED GENTLEMAN - Rev. 4/3/92             87.
Dodge indicates his bloodhound nose.

He'll listen to you, Tommy. I want you to go make peace between us. Tell him we'll work something out on his amendments -- not a vote, I won't go that far, but at least he'll get to say his piece on the floor. Just get him off my back. Can you do that for me?
That's not a question, is it?
That's right.     Is there a problem?
No, no -- I've still got my right nut, I can work with that.
A WAITER removes an empty pitcher of beer.
Another?
Sure, why not. Marshall takes a boiled crab from the platter between the places it on the butcher paper in front of him, christens it --
The honorable Dick Dodge. -- raises a big wooden mallet, and SMASHES it on the crab smiling.
You know, Eli, sometimes people do things they regret. Everyone makes mistakes. Fact is, Dick's been under a lot of pressure lately --
That man's a walking quid quo pro -- prid quo -- quid pro quo, and you know it. He put you up to this, didn't he?
THE DISTINGUISHED GENTLEMAN - Rev. 4/3/92             88.
What do you mean?
Don't shit me, Tommy. You're Dick Dodge's yes-man. I know what you're up to. This is damage control.
I'm not a yes-man. When Dick says no, I say no. Marshall SMASHES down again with the mallet.    Crab carn

You know why no one on the Hill drops a dime on anyone else? Mutual assured destruction. Our little gentleman's agreement. Everybody has something on somebody, so nobody has anything on anybody, because everybody wants to save his own ass.
(interested)
Oh, yeah? What do they have on you?
They think I'm a pompous ass.
Shit, that ain't no secret.
Reinhardt and Loretta about to go in.
You sure they don't want to be alone, Reinhardt?
No, no -- I bet they've been talking about the ethics bill all night. Come on, Loretta, you'll know how to get Marshall's mind off business.
Shit, this place isn't about passing laws any more. It isn't about doing good any more. All it's about is... being here.
THE DISTINGUISHED GENTLEMAN - Rev. 4/3/92             88A
Loretta and Reinhardt approach their table.
Well, as I live and breathe.   Tommy! Tommy is surprised to see them.   She flashes a smile at Marshall.
Eli, this is Loretta Hicks, from my staff. Loretta, Congressman Marshall.
Pleasure to meet you.
Entirely mine.
You know Reinhardt, my AA? Marshall nods.   Reinhardt turns to Tommy.
Excuse me, congressman, could I just do a couple of quick calendar things with you?
(to Loretta)
Would you care for a drink?
Tell you the truth, nothing for me.
Well, when a pretty lady shoots him down, an old man knows it's time to go home. Marshall rises, pulling out his car keys.
You kids have a good time.
(indicating pitcher)
Listen, you gentlemen look like you've had a few -- Loretta, why don't you be a designated driver? Loretta stands and takes Marshall's keys from him.
THE DISTINGUISHED GENTLEMAN - Rev. 4/3/92             89.
Excellent idea.
Ah.    The good Samaritan.
Good night, y'all. They leave.
Now we've already got the Bankruptcy Institute breakfast tomorrow, but if you don't mind we could wedge in the Prune Board -- This isn't what Tommy wants to be doing now.    He gets u
I'm packing it in.
(also rising)
Can we talk while I drive you?
Thanks, I'll walk. I could use the air.
Marshall and Loretta are singing. MARSHALL and LORETTA
"Amazing grace, how sweet the sound, that saved a wretch like me -- "
Tommy is on foot. Marshall's car, with its Maryland congressional plates, pulls over.
sense_profile: Marshall 's car , with its Maryland congressional plates ,

text: Come on, honey, no use you getting mugged.
MARSHALL and LORETTA

"I once was lost, but now am found; was blind, but now I see... " Tommy, in the back, cradles his head.   As Loretta heads into a traffic circle, she SEES THE DISTINGUISHED GENTLEMAN - Rev. 4/3/92             90.
in high sling-back heels.
(turning to look)
Check out the fuck-me pumps on that. Mm-mm. I gotta get me some shoes like that.
Loretta!   Please! Your mouth!
With a SCREECH of brakes and a CRUNCH of metal, a TAXI rear-ends them, SLAMMING Marshall's car into a lamppost.
The Taxi Driver looks at the wreck for a moment.   Then he lays rubber and SQUEALS away.

On the back floor, Tommy stirs. Seems to be okay. Lifts himself to see up front. The windshield is smashed. Loretta and Marshall are both unconscious. Tommy climbs into the front but can't get the door open. He kicks out a broken window and climbs through. He runs to a phone on the corner and dials 911.
I need an ambulance right away. IN THE CAR no motion from Loretta or Marshall. AT THE PHONE he dials another number.
Evening, Mrs. Dodge, Tommy Johnson here, sorry to call at this hour, is Dick back from the Gridiron dinner yet? Could I speak with him for just a moment?
MRS. DODGE is in bed. She hands the phone to Dodge, who's in white tie and tails, looking more sinister than splendid.
Tommy Johnson.
THE DISTINGUISHED GENTLEMAN - Rev. 4/3/92           91.
(into phone)
What's wrong? INTERCUT Tommy and Dodge.
How did you know?
Good news doesn't come at this hour.
I went out with Marshall. We got into an accident. He's out cold. I'm okay. Dodge looks off balance.
Were you driving?
No.   Someone else. Loretta. Dodge recovers his equilibrium.
The girl from your office?
Yeah. She's out, too. I don't like the way it looks. For anybody. Look. You said you wanted to get back into Marshall's good graces. Well, here's an opportunity.

Listen carefully. Tell the ambulance to take you to Walter Reed. It's a privilege they give congressmen. It's also the only hospital without a bunch of goddam reporters shtupping the nurses in exchange for leaks. They'll keep it quiet. I'll handle the police. You go home and keep your mouth shut.

Two figures approach one another in the shadows: Reinhardt, and the Taxi Driver who rear-ended Marshall's car. The cabbie nods.   Reinhardt hands him an envelope. The Driver inspects the cash. THE DISTINGUISHED GENTLEMAN - Rev. 4/3/92             91A
Tommy is shaving.   He HEARS the local tv news from the bedroom.

... and the Beltway is bumper-to bumper, so you might as well take a day of annual leave and enjoy yourself. At the top of the news, Maryland Congressman Elijah Marshall is in satisfactory condition at Walter Reed Hospital after an overnight accident in the District. Tommy bolts into the bedroom.    On the television he see
A CORRESPONDENT doing a stand-up.
That's right, Tom. Marshall reportedly had alcohol in his blood. Also slightly injured was an unidentified woman whom police say has a record in several states for prostitution. Tommy looks sick.
Oh sweet Jesus.
Linda, Congressman Marshall -- that's Reverend Marshall, isn't it?
Right you are, Tom. How this plays into his longstanding campaign to reform congressinoal ethics is now anyone's guess.
Thank you.   In other news... Tommy leaps for his clothes.
Tommy races down the corridor.   Ahead of him, Celia, coming out of Marshall's room.   She freezes at the sight of him.
THE DISTINGUISHED GENTLEMAN - Rev. 4/3/92              92
Get away from him. He approaches her.
And get away from me.
I have to talk to you.
Go away!
I was set up!
You were set up? You were in the car! I didn't hear your name on the news!
No, someone screwed him --
"Someone"?
Celia, something stinks here --
Yeah -- it's you! You don't give a damn about anything! And to think, the other night, I actually thought you cared about someone else. He puts his hand to her face.    She brushes it off.

Not me, you jerk -- Mickey Juba! You caved on those power lines, didn't you? I knew it. Damn it, I knew it! What did you get for it? Tommy O'Connor's box at the Redskins? Someone slip you a condo in the Virgin Islands?
If you'd give me a chance to --
THE DISTINGUISHED GENTLEMAN - Rev. 4/3/92               9
God, I hate this town -- the only reason I stay is because I hate it so much.
Celia --
Get the hell out of here.
sitting on the ground, backs to us, beneath the power lines. A quiet moment. REVERSE ANGLE - TWO SHOT.   Mickey is shuffling a deck of cards.
Is it thumb over, or thumb under?
Under. She tries her hand at a false shuffle.
Not bad, kid.    You've got potential.
So what's happening? I thought you were going to kick some ass on -- She indicates the derricks.      Tommy looks at her, come a decision.
I am. He takes the deck from her, fans it face up, pulls all th kings and aces, stacks them on top, and squares the deck.
This is one's called the double duke. How many players?
Six.
Who's the mark?
THE DISTINGUISHED GENTLEMAN - Rev. 4/3/92            94.
She points to an imaginary poker player.
Number two -- over there. Tommy, smiling, calculates something for a moment, then gives the deck four shuffles. He hands Mickey the cards.
Your deal. She deals out six hands in a circle on the ground.
Look at the sucker's hand. She turns over the hand at number two.   It has the four kings. Mickey WHISTLES at the hand.
Look at your hand. She turns over her own hand. It has the four aces. Mickey looks at the power lines, at the hands, at TJ. Then, understanding:
That's what you're going to do? Tommy nods.   Her face opens into a big smile.
Let's kick some ass.    What do I do?
Something very important.
Tommy pow-wows with Loretta Van Dyke, and Armando.   Asid from a sling, Loretta looks okay.
Why are we meeting here, Tommy? There trouble at the office?
(impersonating Dodge)
"I keep my ear close to the ground." His ear my ass. He had an inside man.
That little fuck Reinhardt?
THE DISTINGUISHED GENTLEMAN - Rev. 4/3/92             95.
Hot damn -- I knew my driving wasn't that bad. Speaking of which -- you think I should wear one of those whiplash things, Tommy? There some insurance angle I should be working here?
We got bigger fish to fry, darlin'.
What do we do?
(beat)
The big con.
We gonna git that sucker.
Dick always said I should think big.
Whoa! Aren't we gettin' out of our league, man? That Dodge is a pro!
You can't con a con, Congressman.
Shit, that's right, Tommy -- these politicians are serious slick fish.

You people gone soft on me? Bunch of fuckin' incumbents I got here. Now listen up. Thursday morning Dodge has a breakfast with the Arts Caucus in the Longworth Room. Armando -- find out how fast I can get from Longworth to my office. Loretta -- we need some scoop from the EPA for the roper, I'll give you a list. Van Dyke -- call Hattie at the Silver Foxes, and --
Wait a minute -- we need a new roper, don't we? Everyone around here knows our faces. Outside a HORN sounds (O.S.).    Tommy looks at his watch
THE DISTINGUISHED GENTLEMAN - Rev. 4/3/92            96.
Right on the nose. He throws open the bay window of the narrow house. Just below is a pickup truck with "Homer's Pit Stop" lettered on the side. Homer gets out.
My man! The others come to the window to see Homer, still wearing his fuel-smeared overalls, and SHOUT greetings.
Now let's get to work.
The Members are being seated for a hearing. At the dais, Tommy approaches Dodge. A beat as Dodge studies Tommy's face.
Eli Marshall caught his tail in a crack, didn't he?
He did.
You kept my name out of it.
I did.
I owe you one.
(pleased)
You learn fast.
Do me one favor, Dick. Next time you pull some heavy shit involving my ass, tip me off, okay?
(indulgent chuckle)
Alright, son. (BANGS gavel)
This hearing of the Power and Enterprise Committee is now in order. The health of America's securities industry --
THE DISTINGUISHED GENTLEMAN - Rev. 4/3/92              97
Reinhardt approaches Tommy and slips him a packet of materials.
(whispering)

Thanks. Listen, Reinhardt, something's come up, and I don't quite know how to handle it. There's a guy from the EPA -- I don't know him -- says he wants to see me. Tonight. Out of the office. Alone, he says. Sound of it makes me nervous. I'd feel better if you were there.
You got it, jefe.
A man waits, alone, in the shadow of a large statue. It's Homer. In a jacket and tie, his stubble shaved off, he looks like a plausible government worker. Tommy and Reinhardt approach.
Mr. Yancey?
(cold)
I thought you'd be alone.
He's my AA. He goes where I go. If you can trust me, you can trust him. Homer eyes Reinhardt a moment, then continues.
Congressman, I have information I think you may want. It's about something going on at the EPA.
What have you got?
I got a wife and three kids, and a note on my house, that's what I got.
THE DISTINGUISHED GENTLEMAN - Rev. 4/3/92            98.
(laughs)
Nothin' comes for nothin' in this town, do it? (to Reinhardt)
You got any cash on you? I'm kind of light.
(whispering)
You can't do that!
(to Homer)
This stuff's pretty good?
In the right hands, it could mean a great deal.
Okay. Sunday. Fifth race at Del Mar. Blueboy is running twenty to one. I'd take a major position.
You have to be shitting me.
No, not at all -- my Cousin Henry spends his days pumping water into horses' stomachs and stuffing Percodan up their butts. Trust me. Reinhardt is interested in this.   And he admires Tommy's m.o.
(after a moment)
Alright. The White House is putting heat on the EPA. They want us to announce a major investigation of the relation between power lines and cancer clusters.
sense_profile: us to announce a major investigation of the relation between power lines and cancer clusters
a major investigation of the relation between power lines and cancer clusters

text: But didn't the EPA already do a study?
Yeah, but when the draft got to the White House, they didn't like it. So they brought their own scientists in to kill it.
THE DISTINGUISHED GENTLEMAN - Rev. 4/3/92            99.
Why did the White House change its mind?
Who knows?
Is there new evidence?
Yeah -- their polls have dropped like a rock. They need an issue. This one makes them look good on the environment, and they don't have to spend a penny.
And what good is this to me?
Come on, congressman, in this town, information is currency. And advance information is gold. Reinhardt nods in agreement.

But you've    got to move fast. Once the White    House goes public with this, they    can't turn back. If your friends at    the power company want to kill this    investigation, they'd better do it now.     Evening, gentlemen. After Homer leaves:
Blueboy. Twenty to one. Is your Cousin Henry always right?
I ain't got no Cousin Henry.
Reinhardt dials.
Hello?
THE DISTINGUISHED GENTLEMAN - Rev. 4/3/92             100
Mrs. Dodge, it's Arthur Reinhardt. May I speak to the Chairman, please?
Hello?
Are you sitting down?
The Longworth Room, a small circular committee room with an ornate rotunda. The Arts Caucus breakfast is ending.
Unless there is further business, our caucus stands adjourned. Dodge gets up.    As he makes to leave, Tommy comes in.
Got a minute, Dick? Tommy takes him aside.    The room empties except for the
Listen, Dick, I heard something. There's got to be some bid'ness in it. Tommy very discreetly gestures with his thumb and palm: money.
Maybe we can go in on it together.
I'm listening.
The EPA is going to make a stink about power lines. The White House is pushing them to do a big study.
That's very interesting, my friend. I've heard that, too.
(acting surprised)
Nothing gets by, do it? Tommy touches his nose, in tribute to the master.
THE DISTINGUISHED GENTLEMAN - Rev. 4/3/92            100A
But thank you, son -- I'm glad you chose to share it with me. We do make quite a team, don't we?
I -- I hope it wasn't my press conference that started this.
No, this is a stunt for the polls.
So do you think there's something in it for us?
(musing)
If we got the EPA off Olaf Andersen's back, he'd be extremely appreciative.
And how do we do that?
My committee writes the EPA's programs. We audit their funds. We confirm their appointees. I've got them by the balls.
And you're going to -- ? Tommy makes a squeezing gesture, grins.
Oh, no, not at all -- just... persuasion. Strenuous persuasion.
That's allowed?
Persuasion, yes. Intimidation, no. But it's a gray area. Who's to say which is which?
Dick, wait a minute -- shouldn't we check out the tip? Make sure the EPA's really going through with this investigation?
THE DISTINGUISHED GENTLEMAN - Rev. 4/3/92             101
Of course. (looks at watch)
He should be in by now.
Who?
Skeeter Warburton, of course. Always go right to the top, son.
Dodge passes his Secretary's desk on the way into his office.
Get me the EPA Administrator, please.
Tommy jogs along the corridor. A tourist Family stares at him. He explains his haste with a smile --
There's a vote on the floor. -- and ducks into the stairwell.

In a chamber crammed with cables, the Telephone Man listens to a handset. He now sports a gold Rolex on his wrist -- his horse must have come in. Van Dyke, also there, looks at any array of dials and meters, whose hands all suddenly move. Some electronic phone CHIRPS, then the filtered RINGING of a call.
Here he comes. The Telephone Man nods, adjusts some wiring, smiles satisfiedly.
And there he goes.
Loretta wears a beaded sling, which adds to her look. She is at Tommy's desk, watching his phone as it RINGS. Tommy comes in.
sense_profile: a beaded sling , which adds to her look

text: THE DISTINGUISHED GENTLEMAN - Rev. 4/3/92             102
The Administrator. Loretta picks up the phone.
Office of the Adminstrator. (listens)
Thank you, I'll put you right through. She hands the phone to Tommy, who mimics the George Plimpton voice.
sense_profile: to Tommy , who mimics the George Plimpton voice

text: Warbuton here. (listens)
Thank you. (waits)
Mr. Chairman! I do hope there's something I can help you with today.
sense_profile: there 's something I can help you with today

text: I need a straight answer from you, Skeeter. Is the White House on your ass about power lines?
Off the record?
Of course.

I was looking forward to some serious sailing this week -- Tish and I have a lovely spot right by Kennebunkport. Instead, here I am at three in the morning, writing testimony to your committee about cancer clusters.
Thanks for your candor, Warburton.
Not at all. You must come sailing with us. Cheers. Bye-bye. Tommy passes the phone back to Loretta.
Next. THE DISTINGUISHED GENTLEMAN - Rev. 4/3/92            102A
Yes?
Zeke Bridges on line two. Andersen punches the button to connect the call.
I'll just put you through to him. She passes the phone to Tommy.
Olaf? (coughs)
Olaf, Zeke Bridges. Listen, you sum' bitch, I'm so mad, I can't sit down to shit. Have you heard what I heard? (wheezes)
INTERCUT with Andersen.
What's that.
The EPA's fixing to make a big stink about power lines and cancer. They're going to serve us up for breakfast.
Wait a minute. There's no scientific proof --

Proof don't mean shit. We're talking politics. They make a federal case out of power lines, I'm screwed. Whole insurance business is screwed. You know how much cash I'd have to pay out in settlements? Even if I stiffed everybody on claims, the legal fees'd be enough to kill me.
I can't believe it.
THE DISTINGUISHED GENTLEMAN - Rev. 4/3/92             103

You better believe it. You're screwed, too. Every hot dog trial lawyer in America soon be lining up to sue both our asses. We got to move on this, Olaf. If I wasn't tied up here, I'd go to Washington myself. Shouldn't you be getting on a plane? Just between us -- you find a way to stop this, I'll find a million bucks if I have to.
A very worried Andersen.
Tommy and Dodge walking along a Capitol hallway.
Olaf will be at my office at five o'clock.
How do we play it?
Cool. Real cool. You just follow my lead.
I don't know how I can help you on this one, Olaf. This is the EPA. This is the President.
This is my lifeblood!
I see that, Olaf, I see that. But in this town, you pick your fights.
This could mean six figures, Dick. Dodge says nothing, but makes his eyebrows fly.
High six figures. Dodge flicks his eyebrows again:   More.
THE DISTINGUISHED GENTLEMAN - Rev. 4/3/92             104
Seven figures?
Between us. It's not that much -- what can you get for half a million these days?
How the hell can I funnel that kind of money to you?
If that's what you want, we can always find a loophole. No one will see your fingerprints.
No one will know?
No one will know.
You're only in trouble if someone can prove a connection.
Of course there's no connection. Olaf's just making a contribution as a patriotic citizen. And in return for it, he's getting --
Good government.
Exactly.   A little access, that's all.
Dodge, Andersen, Tommy, and O'Connor walking along. Up ahead, a cocktail reception. On an easel by the door:

head_text.subj: HAZARDOUS WASTE ASSOCIATION MEET YOUR REPRESENTATIVE NIGH

text: I've got to do a drop-by. You gentlemen like to join me for a drink?
Dodge and Tommy work the room genially. Tommy spots Celia talking to some Guests and goes over to her.
THE DISTINGUISHED GENTLEMAN - Rev. 4/3/92            105.
Hi.
(to Guests, smiling)
Excuse me. She turns, starts to walk away.   Tommy stops her.
Look. Whatever you think of me, just promise me one thing. She glares at him angrily.   But then she's surprised to hear:
Come to the Clean Air hearing tomorrow.
(baffled)
What?
Power and Enterprise.    Noon.
But why? He gives her an enigmatic smile and slips away. As he rejoins Dodge, Tommy SEES WARBURTON enter the room. Alarmed, TOmmy moves in on Dodge, steering him to avoid the EPA Administrator.
Shouldn't we be heading off, Dick?
Let's work the room just a bit more.
Congressman!   Mr. Chairman! As Dodge turns to see him --
Evening, Reinhardt. -- he SEES Warburton.
THE DISTINGUISHED GENTLEMAN - Rev. 4/3/92            106.
Good to see you, sir.    By the way, I thought your opening   statement in committee yesterday was   brilliant. Dodge points out Warburton to Tommy.
Well. Look who's over there -- Skeeter Warburton from the EPA. The very man we want to see.
(trying to turn him)
Have you tried the oysters, Dick?
At a hazardous waste event? (shakes head)
I think we'll go talk to him.
No, he's the wrong man --
(bemused by Tommy)
You don't understand -- he's the perfect man.
But -- but you don't want to bother him with this. Talk to one of his underlings -- Dodge looks at Tommy with curiosity, not understanding hi reluctance.
Nothing beats man-to-man.
Here?     Not here!
A public place. What could be better?
But it's the wrong time!
While the iron is hot, son.
THE DISTINGUISHED GENTLEMAN - Rev. 4/3/92               1
(chiming in helpfully)
No time like the present.
Shut up, Reinhardt, I'm talking to the Chairman. Beat it, okay?
(smiling to Dodge)
I'll go get him. Reinhardt heads for Warburton.
(puts hand on abdomen)
You heard about this stomach thing going around?
Come on, son, we've got the people's business to do. He leads Tommy off to one side.      Reinhardt brings Warburton to them.
Mr. Chairman.    Congressman.
I've got a big problem, Skeeter.
What's that?
Your power lines investigation.
What power lines investigation? Tommy is sweating bullets.
We're off the record, Skeeter. This witch-hunt for cancer clusters is bad news for everyone.
I don't know what you're talking about, Dick.
THE DISTINGUISHED GENTLEMAN - Rev. 4/3/92             108
Alright, I know you're being a good soldier --
No, I'm being straight with you --

Then let me be straight with you. You announce this study -- I'm not talking about the results down the road, mind you, I'm just talking about the announcement -- and there's broken crockery everywhere. Real estate. Utilities. Insurance. Schools. Local governments. It'll cost jobs. Uproot families.
I agree with you completely. There isn't going to be an investigation, old chap, I promise you.
(beat)
I'm glad we understand each other.
(beat)
Yes, I think we do. Tommy silently rejoices in his good fortune.
And we'll just forget about that phone call this morning?
We didn't speak on the phone.
(vastly impressed)
Excellent. Dodge claps him on the shoulder, then heads off with Tomm who is delighted to have dodged a bullet.
(imitating Warburton)
"There isn't going to be an investigation, old chap."
(chuckling)
You're bad.
THE DISTINGUISHED GENTLEMAN - Rev. 4/3/92           109.
They join up with Andersen and O'Connor.
(sotto voce)
Worked like a charm. We scared him shitless. The investigation's dead.
Waiter! Champagne! (to Dodge)
See you at the Clear Air hearings.
As Reinhardt comes into the office, Tommy intercepts him.
Morning, Reinhardt! Got a minute? I need your advice on something.
Sure. Tommy leads him back into the corridor.
Van Dyke, Armando, and Loretta work the phones.
Is this the assignment desk? Yes, I'm calling from Chairman Dodge's office, on the Hill. We wanted to be sure CNN was sending a crew to the Clean Air hearing today.
No, not the new emission standards. We're breaking news. This is the biggest thing since Watergate.
This is Cynthia Leeson in the White House Press Office. My boss wanted me to let you folks know -- we're making a major announcement at the Clean Air hearings today. (listens)
No, I can't tell you, but it's hot. (listens)
Well, if the New York Times wants to be the only paper in town to miss the story of the year, that's up to y'all. THE DISTINGUISHED GENTLEMAN - Rev. 4/3/92              10
sense_profile: to be the only paper in town to miss the story of the year

text: Tommy has drawn Reinhardt into the cage.

I want to do a little    something nice for Dodge. That     EPA thing -- he's been good to me,    Reinhardt. Is there some way I can,    like, throw a bouquet to him at the    hearing today without having to sit    through that boring testimony    shit?
Why don't you ask him to give you the floor at the start?
He's do that?
For some flattery? In a New York minute. Just tip him ahead of time.
Good thinking. They return to the corridor.     Tommy looks at his watch
Say, Reinhardt, my Grandma's plane comes in at ten. You wouldn't mind picking her up and driving Miss Daisy around, would you?
Can't one of the others do it?
No, I don't trust them the way I trust you. TOMMY pats him on the back and sends him on his way.
Tommy, joined by his cronies and the Jubas.
This is it, people.     Game time.   Let's get it right.
Tell me one thing, jefe. How do you know Andersen is going to bite?
I don't.   You run a con, you run a risk. THE DISTINGUISHED GENTLEMAN - Rev. 4/3/92             110

A hundred or so members of the public -- trade groups, Hill staffers, lawyers, tourists -- settle into their seats. VAN DYKE escorts Hattie Rifkin and a busload of Silver Foxes. Loretta comes in with Ellen and Mickey Juba. GRANDMA comes in, on Reinhardt's arm. She is dressed up as a biddy, down to a hat with fruit on it. COMMITTEE MEMBERS head for their seats at the dais. OLAF ANDERSEN is at the witness table, along with a coupl of other businessmen. In a seat behind Andersen, Tommy O'Connor. THE PRESS.   A good turnout, with several camera crews.
sense_profile: Hattie Rifkin and a busload of Silver Foxes

text: You know what this is?
(confidential)
It's very hot. Electric cars. CELIA is seated with Ira, her Pro Bono associate.
I'm cutting out early.
(indicating TJ)
Don't want to run into him?
You got that right. AT THE DAIS Tommy has a private word with Dodge.

Dick, I thought it might be a nice way to open if I congratulated you on the fine work you been doin' on this committee. Really express our appreciation. Especially on behalf of the minority community.
Why, thank you, son.
THE DISTINGUISHED GENTLEMAN - Rev. 4/3/92            111.
(indicating cameras)
Wouldn't hurt to have tape like that in the bank, would it, Mr. Speaker? HOMER slips in next to Reinhardt, who is surprised to see him.
sense_profile: to have tape like that in the bank

text: Mr. Yancey? Arthur Reinhardt.      Are you testifying for the agency?
(leaning over)
Hello, Homer, dear.
No, Mrs. Johnson, you must be mistaken -- let me introduce you. This is Mr. Yancey of the EPA.
(to Reinhardt)
Don't be silly, child.
Homer Norton. Homer's Pit Stop, Axahatchee, Florida.
Homer's known Tommy since they were in diapers.
(getting up)
What the -- ? From the row behind Reinhardt, Armando clamps Reinhardt down.
Move and you're history. DODGE GAVELS the meeting to order.

This meeting of the Power and Enterprise Committee to consider the reauthorization of the Clean Air Act is now in session. Today's first business is a panel of national leaders in the field of utilities.
THE DISTINGUISHED GENTLEMAN - Rev. 4/3/92            112.
Before I welcome them, Chair would like to yield to the gentleman from Florida for a word. If there is no objection from the Committee -- ? The gentleman may proceed.

Mr. Chairman, on behalf of the other members of this committee, and on behalf of myself, I have a very personal statement to make. From the bottom of my heart, I want to thank you -- thank you for your leadership, for your insight, for your boldness... Dodge preens for the cameras, until:
... and for your courage. Especially your courage.
(surprised)
My courage?
Your courage in exposing the corruption that eats away at this institution. Your courage in taking on the special interests. Your courage in taking a major new step --
But I've... I've... I've done nothing new, nothing at all -- what are you talking about?

You're    right -- integrity isn't new to you,    Mr. Chairman, it's second nature    to you. Still it's a rare public    servant who'll take on the special    interest money, take on the PACs -- ANDERSEN, wary, senses danger.
take on the lobbyists and fat cats -- CELIA is fascinated.
THE DISTINGUISHED GENTLEMAN - Rev. 4/3/92            113.
... and who'll stand up instead for ordinary American citizens...
... the plain people who just want peace of mind -- who just want to know they're raising their kids in safe neighborhoods and sending them to safe schools. ON THE DAIS Dodge wants to wrap this up.
Yes, courage, Mr. Chairman, is a quality that you have in abundance --
Well, yes, thank you, but we have to move along, if the gentleman would --
(undeterred)
Ladies and gentlemen, yesterday, the Chairman and I had a meeting in his office with Olaf Andersen of Gulf Coast Power, and his lobbyist, Mr. Tommy O'Connor -- (indicating)

these gentlemen here. Chairman Dodge and I listened in astonishment as Olaf Andersen offered us seven figures -- that's one million dollars, ladies and gentlemen. A BUZZ in the room.   O'CONNOR leans forward to Andersen.
Dodge double-crossed us.
You're fired.
One million dollars, if we would stop the EPA from investigating the connection between power lines and cancer clusters.
THE DISTINGUISHED GENTLEMAN - Rev. 4/3/92            114.
Shocked MURMURS sweep the room. REINHARDT is aghast. HOMER and ARMANDO are delighted.
Isn't that right, Mr. Andersen? Tommy flicks his eyebrows at Andersen, provocatively, imitating Dodge.
That's a vicious lie. Dodge GAVELS sharply, turns to Tommy.
Will the gentleman yield?
That's not possible! You can't give anyone that kind of money! Dodge continues GAVELING.
Oh, yes, you can. As Mr. O'Connor said to you, quote: "If that's what you want, we can always find a loophole. No one will know." Remember saying that, Tommy?
I do not!
(standing)
I insist that the gentlemen yield! Tommy also stands, and produces a video tape.
You can't deny it, Mr. Andersen! We have the whole thing on this tape! The room erupts. THE PRESS loves it. Still cameras CLICK and WHIR. DODGE despairs. REINHARDT puts his hand over his face.
Yesterday, at Chairman Dodge's courageous suggestion, I taped the whole conversation. It's all there. Mr. Chairman, I thank you. The people thank you. America thanks you.
THE DISTINGUISHED GENTLEMAN - Rev. 4/3/92               1

AUDIENCE APPLAUDS DODGE. The clapping is considerably sweetened by the Panthers and the rest of Tommy's claque. DODGE gauges their reaction, gets an inspiration. The storm leaves his face, and becomes a smile, which he beams on Tommy.
I thank the distinguished gentleman. And I thank my fellow citizens. Our methods in this investigation may have been unorthodox, but together -- (indignant, at Andersen)

we have exposed a canker at the very heart of democracy. APPLAUSE. Tommy is amazed at Dodge's survival skills. REINHARDT, delighted at the turn, claps heartily. ANDERSEN, livid, leaps up and shouts at Dodge.
You bastard!    You set me up!
Witness is out of order!
You stood to make a million bucks off of me! Who offered you more? I want to know! A new BUZZ sweeps the room. O'Connor tries to restrain Andersen, who sloughs him off.
You're as big a whore as he is! MICKEY JUBA catches Tommy's eye and mouths a question.
Now? Tommy shakes his head:   no.
The phone by Eli Marshall's bed RINGS.    He answers.
Hello?  No. You're joking. (to Man in next bed)
You mind if I put on C-span? THE DISTINGUISHED GENTLEMAN - Rev. 4/3/92            116.

There's no loyalty any more, is there, Dick? What about the three hundred grand you squeezed from me for that goddam voter registration front of yours -- that just water under the bridge? O'Connor tries again to restrain him.
Don't touch me, you scum! MICKEY JUBA mouths:
Now? Tommy shakes his head again.    No.

What about the two hundred k for your phony foundation, Dick? How about the ten thousand copies if your goddam autobiography you muscled me to buy -- what's all that, ancient history? Andersen advances toward the dais, pointing now to six or seven other Members of the Committee among the total of 28.

And you -- what about those bundled checks from my executives? I gave you my condo in Vail! I gave you my corporate jet to fly all over the world! I gave your kids summer jobs! I put up scholarships to put your kids through college! I hired your goddam wife to redecorate my office! You telling me none of that counts for anything? Andersen grabs Dodge by the throat.
I thought you people were for sale! I was wrong -- you're just for rent! Dodge struggles free of Andersen, who is dragged away fro Dodge by Capitol Police.
THE DISTINGUISHED GENTLEMAN - Rev. 4/3/92              11
How dare you impugn my integrity! Everything I've done has been completely legal!
(acting astonished)
Mr. Chairman! You mean to say you did all that stuff? You took all that money? Shock in the room. Some BOOS. IOWA does a nice HOG CALL. TJ sends a little wave and smile to Celia.
sense_profile: to say you did all that stuff

text: There's nothing I've done that -- (indicating other Members)
-- that these gentlemen haven't done! Committee Members rush to dissociate themselves from Dodge.
No!... Not me!... Just him!... I never!... He crossed the line!
They're whores! All of them! MICKEY JUBA tries again.
Now? TJ nods yes.
Throw the bums out! LAUGHTER and APPLAUSE.   She's touched a nerve.   TJ leap into the moment.
Damn straight! Throw the bums out! This place is an outhouse! ON THE PUBLIC. GASPS, WHOOPS, and APPLAUSE.    Reinhardt sinks lower and lower into his seat.
(calling)
Throw the bums out! Throw the bums out!
THE DISTINGUISHED GENTLEMAN - Rev. 4/3/92            118.
Tommy, enjoying the triumph, can't help rubbing Dodge's n in it.
I owed you one. Dodge wheels on Tommy, exploding.
You lowlife hustler! Who are you to talk? You got into this House through fraud. You think I didn't check up on you? He pulls a piece of paper from the pile at his place.
Ladies and   gentlemen, I have here some rather   startling revelations about this   Mr. Johnson before you. This man is   nothing but a con man! A fresh BUZZ from the room.
A common grifter! (consulting paper)
He's wanted in three counties for bunco! He's a convicted swindler! Some BOOS.   REINHARDT emerges from his hole, encouraged.
A fugitive from justice for card sharping, bookmaking, confidence games --
-- and other charges the FBI has only begun to investigate! I dare you to respond! A hush in the room.
You know what? He's right!     But let me tell you something --   all that's nothing, compared to   what I pulled here in Washington...   and this shit's all legit!
THE DISTINGUISHED GENTLEMAN - Rev. 4/3/92            119.
LAUGHTER and APPLAUSE.   Dodge BANGS the gavel repeatedly
The gentleman is out of order! The gentleman is out of order! This committee is adjourned! GRANDMA leaps to her feet.
Stop banging! Stop banging!      That man has something to say! Massive APPLAUSE. Dodge is stunned by the enormity of the sentiment against him.
Adjourned? Fine. Leave. (indicating cameras)
Turn your backs on the whole country. That what you want to do, gentlemen? The Members remain in place, paralyzed.
(to the room)

I'm a con man. A small-time con man. Do you know what it was like for me to come to Congress? It was for like dying and going to heaven. If I did back home the kind of scams I've run in Congress, my ass would be in Sing Sing. But no, I'm not a crook -- up here, I'm a distinguished gentleman!
sense_profile: what it was like for me to come to Congress

text: Eli, watching on television.
Now don't get me wrong. They're not all bums. But boy, do the rotten fish stink up the barrel. Marshall APPLAUDS.   The Man in the next bed joins in.
Now tell me, people -- while these guys are buying and selling each other, who's standing up for you?
THE DISTINGUISHED GENTLEMAN - Rev. 4/3/92            120.

I'll tell you who. Nobody! Nobody gets five hundred bucks an hour to lobby for the average Joe! There's no Shnook PAC! There's no National Association for Ordinary Assholes! Sure, everyone's against cancer, but "everyone" doesn't have an office on K Street! (to committee Members)

Don't you folks get it? We're supposed to be the people's lobbyists. Congress is supposed to be America's political action committee. APPLAUSE and SHOUTS of support. Several Members on the dais join the applause, seeing a winning issue. CELIA shakes her head in wonder. Tommy goes to Mickey and stands her up on a chair.
She's right. Throw the bums out -- starting with me! I'm gonna found me a new party. The Don't Vote For Me Party. Any of y'all want to join up? APPLAUSE and CALLS of enthusiasm.
Well, come on, then! C'mon, get up, we got work to do! The room erupts, electrified, chanting.

Throw the bums out! Throw the bums out! Tommy is engulfed by people and lights. Dodge, Andersen, and O'Connor -- desperate, snarling -- are pinned to the wall by the SHOUTING Press Corps. Loretta AND GRANDMA watch Tommy bask in his new notoriety.
That Miss Oprah's gonna love his ass.
THE DISTINGUISHED GENTLEMAN - Rev. 4/3/92               1
CELIA arrives where Tommy is standing.   She looks at him a beat. Then a big smile. They kiss.
Tommy Johnson. Kamikaze congressman.
Tommy and Celia walk down the steps, arm in arm.
I can't wait to see that tape you made. Tommy pulls it from his pocket, glances at it, and tosses it away.
Why? I bought it this morning. It's blank. As they continue down the steps, CAMERA CRANES UP to WIDE SHOT of the Capitol and the town beyond.
